title: State v. Davis
description: The court concludes that the false information contained in an affidavit leading to the issuance of a search warrant did not, in this case, justify suppression of evidence obtained as a result of the warrant.
text:
State v. Craig D. Davis


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Appellant,
v.
Craig Duval Davis, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
DanielÂ  F. Pieper, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4183
Heard November 6, 2006 â€“ Filed December 11, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Appellant.Â  
John S. Nichols, of Columbia, Â for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The State appeals the grant of Craig Davisâ€™ motion to suppress evidence obtained pursuant to a search warrant procured with false information.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
On December 31, 2004, the Conway Police Department received reports of multiple shots fired in a residential area.Â  Off-duty City Police Officer Rodrick Mishoe lived in the area, and one of the shots entered his residence.Â  Officer Mishoe looked out his window and saw a black male running up the street firing a gun, and another black male, wearing a ski mask, standing at the edge of his yard.Â  When police arrived on the scene, Officer Mishoe said from the â€œlips,â€ â€œeyes,â€ â€œfacial features,â€ and body structure he believed the person in the ski mask was a man who lived behind him.Â  The man went by the nickname â€œChubby.â€Â  Tyrone Williams, one of the responding officers, knew that Craig Duval Davis went by the nickname â€œChubby.â€ Â Officer Williams shared this information with Detective Sergeant Tammy Staples, who then obtained a photograph of Craig Davis from the J. Rubin Long Detention Center.Â  Staples showed the photograph to Mishoe, who confirmed that the subject was the person he knew as â€œChubby.â€Â  
Police officers proceeded to Davisâ€™ residence without an arrest warrant or search warrant.Â  Upon arriving, officers observed Davis and another individual exit a shed located at the back of the property.Â  The men complied with the officersâ€™ requests to get down on the ground.Â  As they did so, a handgun protruding from the back of Davisâ€™ waistband became clearly visible.Â  A search of the two subjects revealed an additional gun on Davis and two weapons on the other individual.Â  Staples sought a search warrant for the shed and submitted an affidavit in support of her request indicating that â€œOfficer Rodrick [sic] positively identified one of the subjects firing shots in his yard as Graig [sic] Davis . . . .â€Â  The search warrant was issued, and a search of the shed revealed another gun, a silencer, cocaine, marijuana, and crack cocaine.Â  Davis was indicted on drugs and weapons charges.Â  At trial, Davis moved to suppress the drug evidence arguing that the search of the shed was based on a falsified affidavit because Mishoe never â€œpositively identifiedâ€ Craig Davis as a suspect.Â  The trial court granted his motion. Â The State appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from a suppression hearing, the appellate court will give deference to the circuit courtâ€™s findings and only reverse if there is clear error. Â State v. Brockman, 339 S.C. 57, 66, 528 S.E.2d 661, 666 (2000).Â  The appellate court may conduct its own review of the record to ascertain if there is any evidence to support the ruling.Â  State v. Khingratsaiphon, 352 S.C. 62, 70, 572 S.E.2d 456, 460-61 (2002).

    LAW/ANALYSIS
The State contends the courtâ€™s suppression of the evidence because it was discovered through a search warrant predicated on false information was error.Â  We agree.Â  
In determining whether alleged misstatements in an affidavit render a search warrant invalid, the court must conduct the analysis set forth in Franks v. Delaware, 438 U.S. 154 (1978).

Franks outlined a two-part test for challenging the warrant affidavitâ€™s veracity.Â  First, to mandate an evidentiary hearing, there must be â€˜allegations of deliberate falsehood or of reckless disregard for the truth . . . and those allegations must be accompanied by an offer of proof.â€™ . . . Second, . . . the court must consider the affidavitâ€™s remaining content, with the affidavitâ€™s false material set to one side, to determine if it is sufficient to establish probable cause.

State v. Davis, 354 S.C. 348, 359-60, 580 S.E.2d 778, 784 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing State v. Missouri, 337 S.C. 548, 524 S.E.2d 394 (1999)) (internal citations omitted).Â  â€œThere will be no Franks violation if the affidavit . . . still contains sufficient information to establish probable cause.â€Â  Missouri, at 554, 524 S.E.2d at 397. Â 
In this case, evidence was presented in camera regarding Mishoeâ€™s alleged positive identification of Davis as one of the men involved in the shootout near his property.Â  Officer Mishoe testified that he was â€œnot positively sureâ€ the suspect was Chubby and that his looking at the photograph of Davis was not a positive identification of Davis as the man in the ski mask.Â  After hearing the testimony, the court concluded that Mishoe had not â€œpositively identifiedâ€ Davis.Â  The statement was therefore false and had been used in the affidavit with reckless disregard for the truth.Â  Because there is evidence in the record to support this finding, we do not disturb it on appeal.Â  
Although the second part of the Franks analysis is not expressly discussed in the record, the trial court indicated that its decision to suppress the evidence was â€œconsistent with Frank [sic] versus Delaware.â€Â  The parties agree the trial court conducted the second part of the Franks analysis as such an examination would be implicit in a ruling under Franks.Â  Therefore, it necessarily follows the trial court determined the remaining information in the affidavit was insufficient to support probable cause to obtain the search warrant.Â  We disagree and conclude the court erred in its analysis.Â  
In many Franks cases, a false statement in the supporting affidavit will render a search warrant defective.Â  However, the facts of this case are unique.Â  Had an arrest warrant or search warrant for the person of Craig Davis been sought prior to the officersâ€™ encounter with the suspects, the false identification in Staplesâ€™ affidavit would have rendered such a warrant fatally defective and any evidence seized as a result would necessarily have been suppressed.Â  However, the in camera testimony of Mishoe indicated he told police that one of the suspects looked like his neighbor, â€œChubby,â€ whom Williams knew to be Craig Davis. Â That tentative identification was sufficient to justify the officers proceeding to Davisâ€™ residence.Â  The sequence of events was logical from an investigative standpoint, and led to the discovery of two individuals emerging from a shed in the rear of the property.Â  The individualsâ€™ compliance with the request to get on the ground revealed a handgun protruding from the waistband of one of the men, which then led to the search of their persons. Â That search then revealed the additional weapons, and the suspects were arrested.[1]Â  After these events transpired, Staples sought the search warrant for the shed.Â  Staplesâ€™ affidavit revealed that two armed men emerged from the shed in a neighborhood where a shooting had very recently occurred. Â In reviewing the affidavit, we believe the unfolding circumstances described therein, not the false statement about a positive identification of Craig Davis, was the basis for the issuance of the search warrant, or at least was information sufficient to justify its issuance.[2]Â  In large measure, therefore, any identification of the suspect contained in the warrant is only coincidental because it was the shed located on the back of the residence that was the subject of the search, not the individual.Â  
Consequently, the decision of the trial court is Â 
 REVERSED AND REMANDED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We make no determination regarding the propriety of Davisâ€™ arrest at the scene.
[2] The relevant portion of the affidavit in its entirety states:Â  

That on December 31, 2004 Officers with the Conway City Police Department responded to the area of Durant Street for multiple shots fired call.Â  Upon officers arrival, they were met by off duty Conway officer Rodrock [sic] Mishoe who advised that he heard the shots being fired and a single round went into his residence.Â  Officer Rodrick [sic] advised that he saw two black males in his front yard area with guns and then he saw them run down John Street.Â  During the investigation it was learned that two subjects in officers yard were firing shots towards three black males [sic] subjects near the end of Durant Street.Â  It was also discovered that shots fired from two subjects in officers yard, penitrated [sic] a residence on Robin Road.Â  Officer Rodrick [sic] positively identified[2] one of the subjects firing shots in his yard as Graig [sic] Davis (B/M 1775 Hemingway Street, Conway, S.C.).Â  Officer went to residence of 1775 Heningway [sic] Street, to locate Graig [sic] Davis.Â  On officers approach to residence, Graig [sic] Davis along with subject 2 â€“ John Fletcher appeared from a shed located behind the residence of 1725 Hemingway Street.Â  For officers safety, subjects were advised to get on the ground, and protruding from the back pant of subject Graig [sic] Davis was a hand gun.Â  A search of each subject was done and a larger hand gun was located in the waist band of subject â€“ Graig [sic] Davis.Â  A search of subject 2 -Â  John Fletcher- revealed he was in possession of two handguns.Â  It is the belief of the affiant that more weapons and ammunition for weapons found will be located inside of wooden shed located behind the residence od [sic] 1725 Hemingway Street.

title: Jones v. Doe
description: The plaintiff appeals a grant of summary judgment to the defendants in this medical malpractice case. The principal concerns in this appeal are (1) whether the trial court should have granted the plaintiff's motion for a continuance of the summary judgment hearing, and (2) whether the plaintiff presented sufficient admissible evidence to create a genuine issue of material fact as to whether the defendants deviated from the applicable standard of care.
text:
Jones v. Doe


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Annie Lee Jones, individually, and as Personal Representative Applicant for the Estate of Katherine Elaine Jones, deceased, and on behalf of her minor children and heirs Khadijah Jones, Keyia Sanders, Robert Canty and Da-Nayia
Sailes, Appellant,
v.
John or Jane Doe (unknown physician), Spartanburg Regional Medical Center,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4184
Heard November 7, 2006 â€“ Filed December 18, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Theo W. Mitchell, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Perry D. Boulier, of Spartanburg, for Respondents.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  This is a medical malpractice case.Â  Annie Lee Jones (Jones), individually and on behalf of the estate of Katherine Elaine Jones (Katherine), contends the trial court erred in failing to grant her motion for a continuance and in granting summary judgment to the defendants in this action.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On November 9, 2001, Katherine was admitted to Spartanburg Regional Medical Center (SRMC) for the birth of her child.Â  The child was delivered by cesarean section the same day. Â Katherine was discharged on November 12, 2001; however, the child remained under medical care at SRMC.Â  According to a postpartum discharge form that Katherine had signed, she was instructed to return to SRMC on November 19, 2001, for an incision check.Â  
During the early hours of November 17, 2001, Katherine was found dead in her apartment.Â  Based on autopsy results, it was determined Katherine â€œdied as a result of internal hemorrhage secondary to partial dehiscenceâ€ of the uterine incision from her cesarean section.Â  The dehiscence of this incision resulted in internal bleeding that caused her death.[1]Â  
On October 31, 2002, Jones, as special administrator of Katherineâ€™s estate, filed this wrongful death and survival action, claiming SRMC employees committed medical malpractice resulting in Katherineâ€™s death.Â  Â The lawsuit was filed against SRMC and â€œJohn or Jane Doe (unknown physician)â€ (collectively Defendants).
In her deposition, Jones testified Katherine was in good spirits when she left SRMC and did not complain about any physical problems resulting from the cesarean section.Â  A day or two later, however, Katherine complained to Jones in a telephone conversation that her stomach hurt and her feet were swelling.Â  Although Jones told Katherine to go to the hospital if the pain became severe and even offered to drive her there, Katherine said she would be all right. Â 
Priscilla Jones, Katherineâ€™s sister, stated in an affidavit that she visited Katherine almost every day after Katherine returned home from SRMC.Â  According to Priscilla, Katherine complained regularly to her about feeling cold and having swollen feet after the procedure.Â  In addition, Priscilla stated she heard Katherine, during a visit with her newborn child at SRMC, make similar complaints to â€œattending medical staff,â€ whom Priscilla did not otherwise identify. Â In her deposition, Priscilla similarly testified she saw Katherine every day from the time she was discharged to the time of her death and the only complaints Katherine had concerned the swelling of her feet.Â  Although Priscilla also testified she was present when Katherine called her doctor to make an appointment, she only heard Katherine say her feet were swollen.Â  
Minnie Montgomery, Katherineâ€™s grandmother, stated in her affidavit Katherine had complained to her numerous times about abdominal pain.Â  According to the affidavit, Montgomery heard Katherine relate she had complained about her abdominal pain to a nurse while visiting her newborn at SRMC the previous day and the nurse said â€œit was just normal after birth symptoms.â€ Â Although Montgomery told Katherine to insist on seeing a doctor, Katherine said she would â€œtry to make it until the appointment [on November 19].â€ Â 
Joel S. Engel, M.D., Jonesâ€™s expert witness, gave his opinion in an affidavit that â€œhad [Katherine] had post-operative medical attention when complaining of her [severe] abdominal pain . . . identification of the incisional disruption and the finding of the hematoperitoneum would have prevented the untimely death of this woman.â€Â  He further stated that â€œ[d]ehiscence of a uterine and/or surgical incision is a known and acceptable risk assuming the operative procedure is performed in an accepted mannerâ€[2]; however, in his deposition, he agreed it was a rare occurrence and acknowledged he had never been personally involved in a similar case. 
Furthermore, when asked during his deposition to summarize his opinions in this case, Engel replied SRMCâ€™s only deviation from the standard of care was its failure to respond in an appropriate manner to Katherineâ€™s alleged complaints of severe abdominal pain that were â€œoutside the normal postoperative complaints.â€[3]Â  Engel further stated he received no records from SRMC suggesting a physician at SRMC had been made aware of any complaints from Katherine regarding abnormal abdominal pain.Â Â Â  He further agreed it was appropriate follow-up care to schedule an appointment for a patient who had just had a cesarean section seven days after her discharge. 
After Engelâ€™s deposition on February 14, 2005, Defendants moved for summary judgment.Â  The Spartanburg County Court of Common Pleas scheduled the motion for a hearing on June 6, 2005, at 3:15 p.m.
According to the record on appeal, on June 6, 2005, at 11:14 a.m., the Spartanburg County Clerk of Court filed a motion by Jonesâ€™s attorney to continue the hearing based on an allegation that Defendants untimely served their memorandum in support of summary judgment and Jonesâ€™s attorney still had not received a transcript of a deposition.Â  Around 12:42 p.m. that same day, Judge John C. Hayes, a visiting judge presiding at the summary judgment hearing, received a faxed letter from Jonesâ€™s attorney advising counsel would not be available that afternoon because he had a divorce hearing in McCormick County that morning.Â  When the case was called, it appears no one on Jonesâ€™s behalf was present.Â  Judge Hayes stated on the record that he called the McCormick County Courthouse and had been informed by the clerk the hearing had concluded â€œbefore lunch,â€ and counsel â€œhad left there saying he was heading to Spartanburg.â€Â  Reasoning counsel had ample time to arrive at the summary judgment hearing, Judge Hayes then allowed Defendantsâ€™ attorney to present arguments concerning both the requests for a continuance and the summary judgment motion.Â  
On June 9, 2005, Judge Hayes issued an order granting summary judgment to Defendants, finding Jones â€œhas not presented any admissible evidence that Defendants were ever contacted by [Katherine] following her discharge on November 12, 2001 with any complaints of post-operative complicationsâ€ and concluding that â€œ[a]s Dr. Engelâ€™s opinions against Defendants are premised on the contention that the Defendants were negligent in failing to provide prompt and timely follow-up care, [Jonesâ€™s] claims fail as a matter of law.â€Â  
Jones moved for reconsideration pursuant to Rules 59 and 60, SCRCP.Â  By order dated June 22, 2005, Judge Hayes denied the motion.Â  Jones then filed this appeal.
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  We disagree with Jones that Judge Hayes erroneously â€œassumed the authorityâ€ of the chief administrative judge in denying her motion for a continuance of the summary judgment hearing.Â  The only legal authority Jones has cited to this court in support of this argument is Rule 40(i)(1), SCRCP.Â  Although that rule concerns requests for continuances, it authorizes â€œthe courtâ€ to grant such requests â€œfor good and sufficient cause.â€[4]Â  Furthermore, the letter counsel faxed requesting postponement of the hearing was addressed to Judge Hayes, notwithstanding he was a visiting judge in the circuit.
2.Â  We further find Judge Hayes committed no abuse of discretion in refusing to continue the summary judgment hearing either for the reasons advanced in Jonesâ€™s formal motion or because of potential scheduling conflicts that were referenced in the subsequent letter that her attorney faxed to the court.[5]Â  Â 
By letter dated May 16, 2005, counsel for Defendants notified Jonesâ€™s attorney the summary judgment motion would be heard on June 6, 2005, at 3:15 p.m. Â It was not until the day of the scheduled hearing that Jones filed a formal motion for a continuance, which was followed by the faxed letter from her attorney advising that he had a hearing in another county that morning. 
Regarding the scheduling conflict, Judge Hayes issued an order on June 21, 2005, in which he acknowledged he may have been under the misapprehension that Jonesâ€™s attorney had left the McCormick County Courthouse at noon rather than at 1:00 p.m.Â  Nevertheless, Judge Hayes determined there was still ample time for counsel to drive to Spartanburg for the summary judgment hearing even if he had departed one hour later than originally assumed and a telephone call could have addressed the situation if he had been running late.Â  Judge Hayes noted he based his finding about the driving time on www.mapquest.com.Â  Jones has not offered anything in her brief on appeal to suggest this source was unreliable.Â  
As to the grounds advanced in Jonesâ€™s formal motion, we hold neither is of sufficient merit to warrant a determination that Judge Hayesâ€™s refusal to continue the hearing amounted to an abuse of discretion.Â  The South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure do not set a deadline for submitting memoranda of law prepared in conjunction with summary judgment motions.Â  In fact, such memoranda are not required at all.Â  Moreover, the deposition that Jones claimed she needed a transcript for had been taken twenty-four days before the scheduled hearing, giving her ample time to move for a continuance.Â  Accordingly, Judge Hayes did not err in refusing to grant the requested continuance.[6]  
3.Â  Turning to the merits of the case, we disagree with Jonesâ€™s contention that summary judgment was improper.
â€œSummary judgment is appropriate when it is clear that there is no genuine issue of material fact and that the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.â€[7]Â  â€œIn reviewing an order of summary judgment, an appellate court applies the same standard as that which the circuit court applied in determining whether to enter the order.â€[8]Â  â€œOn appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party below.â€[9]Â  
A plaintiff alleging medical malpractice must provide evidence of (1) â€œthe generally recognized practices and procedures which would be exercised by competent practitioners in a defendant doctorâ€™s field of medicine under the same or similar circumstances,â€[10] and (2) a departure by the defendantÂ  â€œfrom the recognized and generally accepted standards, practices and procedures in the manner alleged by the plaintiff.â€[11]Â  In addition, there must be evidence that the defendantâ€™s failure to meet the recognized standard of care was the proximate cause of the plaintiffâ€™s alleged injuries and damages.[12]Â  
In the present case, Engel opined Defendants departed from the standard of medical care in failing to provide post-operative medical attention to Katherine after she complained of severe abdominal pain.Â  Absent, however, is any admissible evidence suggesting that anyone responsible for Katherineâ€™s care and treatment, physician or otherwise, was made aware of her abdominal pain.
Here, Priscilla Jonesâ€™s affidavit and deposition were the only evidence that a witness actually heard Katherine voice any complaints to hospital personnel.Â  As we have recounted earlier in this opinion, Priscilla stated in her affidavit that she heard Katherine tell a nurse that her feet were swollen and she had been feeling cold.Â  Likewise, in her deposition, Priscilla testified she heard Katherine telephone her doctor for an appointment; however, she only recalled Katherine complaining about her swollen feet.Â  In neither instance did Priscilla attest to hearing Katherine tell anyone at SRMC that she was experiencing abdominal pain.Â  
Although Jones testified she heard about Katherineâ€™s abdominal pain from Katherine herself, Jones never stated she was present during any conversations that Katherine may have had with staff members at SRMC.Â  Montgomeryâ€™s affidavit indicates Montgomery had, at best, hearsay knowledge about Katherineâ€™s complaints to medical personnel about her abdominal pain.Â  Finally, as noted in footnote 6 of this opinion, Jones does not specifically take issue with Judge Hayesâ€™s finding that any claim by Montgomery in her deposition that she knew Katherine sought medical care for her abdominal pain was actually hearsay testimony. [13] 
4.Â  Finally, Jones appears to argue Judge Hayes failed to give due consideration to an undated, unsigned document entitled â€œStatement of Annie Jones,â€ in which Jones purportedly averred Katherine â€œsaid for four days that she had been repeatedly calling the doctor, complaining of constant severe abdominal pain, but the doctor neglected to schedule an appointment to see her until finally an appointment was given for November 19, 2001 â€“ however, she died on November 17, 2001.â€ Â In support of this argument, Jones notes in her brief that Engel acknowledged he reviewed this document, which was provided to him by Jonesâ€™s attorney.Â  The implication appears to be that, notwithstanding the hearsay characteristics of the statement at issue and the fact that the document itself lacked authentication, the statement and document were admissible as factual evidence because they formed the basis of Engelâ€™s opinion.Â  We disagree.Â  
Although Jones does not cite any particular rule of evidence in her brief, she apparently relies on Rule 703, SCRE.Â  This rule permits an expert giving an opinion to rely on facts or data â€œthat are not admitted in evidence or even admissible into evidence.â€[14] Â The rule, however, does not allow for the unqualified admission of hearsay evidence merely because an expert has used it in forming an opinion.Â  Rather, as aptly set forth in one treatise:

[T]he expert may testify to evidence even though it is inadmissible under the hearsay rule, but allowing the evidence to be received for this purpose does not mean it is admitted for its truth.Â  It is received only for the limited purpose of informing the jury of the basis of the expertâ€™s opinion and therefore does not constitute a true hearsay exception.[15]

Applying this interpretation of Rule 703 to the present case, we hold that, even if Jones is correct that Engel â€œhad information about complaints by [Katherine] to the Hospital or any physician in the unsigned, undated, typewritten â€˜Statement of Annie Jones,â€™ â€ the document and the assertion that Katherine â€œsaid for four days that she had been repeatedly calling the doctor, complaining of constant abdominal painâ€ were, at best, admissible only to explain how Engel reached his determination regarding whether there was a breach of a duty in this case.Â  Neither the document nor the statement within it could have been admitted as evidence that someone responsible for Katherineâ€™s care and treatment at SRMC was alerted to her complaints of abdominal pain.Â  Absent such evidence, Jones has failed to present a genuine issue of material fact as to whether Defendants deviated from the applicable standard of care.
 AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  The term â€œdehiscenceâ€ has been defined as â€œ[a] bursting open, as of a graafian follical or a wound, esp. a surgical abdominal wound.â€Â  Taberâ€™s Cyclopedic Medical Dictionary 507 (17th ed. 1993).
[2]Â  Priscilla stated in her affidavit she was present during the surgery and heard one of the doctors performing the cesarean section say â€œOh-ohâ€ â€œin an alarming manner, as though a mistake had been madeâ€ and, when she asked if anything was wrong, a physician said, â€œWeâ€™ll take care of it.â€Â  Despite this allegation, there was no attempt to develop the theory that Katherineâ€™s death resulted from the surgery itself.
[3] Although Engel testified no dictated operative report was present in Katherineâ€™s file and stated this omission was â€œone glaring deficiency in the records,â€ there was no showing that Jones made any attempt to obtain such a report or that the absence of the report was proximately linked to the damages claimed in this lawsuit.
[4]Â  Rule 40(i)(1), SCRCP.Â  Although paragraph (h) of Rule 40 requires â€œ[t]he Chief Judge for Administrative Purposes, in cooperation with the clerkâ€ to be â€œresponsible for setting all matters on the Nonjury Docket for disposition,â€ the rule does not specify that scheduling changes need approval from the chief administrative judge.
[5]Â  See Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 309, 486 S.E.2d 750, 760 (1997) (stating a ruling on a motion for a continuance is within the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion).
[6]Â  In her formal motion for a continuance, Jones alleged as good cause for a continuance that SRMC â€œchallenges the affidavit of Plaintiffâ€™s witness Minnie Montgomery, who was deposed Friday, May 13, 2005, and whose requested deposition transcript has not been received by Plaintiff, and to provide said transcript to Plaintiffâ€™s medical expert as an additional basis for his opinion . . . .â€ Â Pursuant to Jonesâ€™s motion for reconsideration, Judge Hayes issued an order in which he noted he read the deposition at issue â€œout of interestâ€ and found the â€œfirsthand knowledgeâ€ Montgomery claimed to have regarding Katherineâ€™s attempt to obtain medical care was actually inadmissible hearsay testimony.Â  Jones does not specifically challenge this finding in her brief.Â  Assuming, then, without deciding that Jones did not receive timely notice that Montgomeryâ€™s affidavit would be challenged, she failed to make a showing on appeal that Montgomeryâ€™s deposition would have cured the defects in the earlier statement.
[7]Â  Gadson v. Hembree, 364 S.C. 316, 320, 613 S.E.2d 533, 535 (2005).
[8]Â  Helms Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 340, 611 S.E.2d 485, 488 (2005).Â  
[9]Â  Willis v. Wu, 362 S.C. 146, 150-51, 607 S.E.2d 63, 65 (2004).
[10] Cox v. Lund, 286 S.C. 410, 414, 334 S.E.2d 116, 118 (1985).Â  
[11] Id.
[12] David v. McLeod Regional Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 248, 626 S.E.2d 1, 4 (2006).
[13] See Rule 208(b)(1)(B), SCACR (â€œOrdinarily, no point will be considered which is not set forth in the statement of the issues on appeal.â€).Â  In any event, we found nothing in Montgomeryâ€™s deposition indicating she heard Katherine report complaints of abdominal pain to appropriate hospital personnel.
[14] Rule 703, SCRE notes.
[15] 2 Kenneth S. Broun, et al., McCormick on Evidence Â§ 324, at 418 (2006) (emphasis added); see also Kim v. Nazarian, 576 N.E.2d 427, 433 (Ill. App. Ct. 1991) (â€œRule 703 does not create an exception to the rule against hearsay because the underlying facts or data are admitted not
for their truth, but for the limited purpose of explaining the basis of the expertâ€™s opinion.â€).

title: Dismuke v. SCDMV
description: The South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles appeals from an order of the circuit court rescinding the Departmentâ€™s suspension of Henry Claude Dismuke, Jr.'s  driver's license.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Henry Claude Dismuke, Jr., Respondent,
v.
South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4185
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 18, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Frank L. Valenta, Jr., and Kelli G. Maddox, both of Blythewood, for Appellant.
James D. Calmes, III, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  Henry Claude Dismuke, Jr. brought this action pursuant to South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 56-1-410 (2006) to reinstate his driverâ€™s license, contending the two-year term for the suspension of his license had run following his plea of guilty to driving with an unlawful alcohol concentration over two years before.Â  By this appeal, the South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles challenges the trial courtâ€™s order rescinding the Departmentâ€™s suspension order.[1]Â  We affirm.[2]
On February 18, 2002, Dismuke pled guilty, as we indicated above, to driving with an unlawful alcohol concentration in violation of South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2933 (2006).Â  The Greenville County Clerk of Court did not forward the ticket relating to Dismukeâ€™s conviction to the Department until June 15, 2005.[3]Â  Upon receipt of the ticket, the Department suspended Dismukeâ€™s driverâ€™s license and notified him the period of his suspension would begin on July 9, 2005 and end on July 9, 2007.Â  Dismuke then brought this action. Â 
At the hearing upon his petition for reinstatement of his license, Dismuke testified he surrendered his license when he pled guilty. Â An employee of the Greenville County Clerk of Court, however, testified nothing on the face of the indictment indicated this had in fact occurred as would usually be the case had it done so.Â  
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2990(F) (2006) provides in part:

Except as provided for in Section 56-1-365(D) and (E), the driverâ€™s license suspension periods under this section begin on the date the person is convicted, receives sentence upon a plea of guilty or of nolo contendere, or forfeits bail posted for the violation of Section 56-5-2930, 56-5-2933 . . . .

Another code section, South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 56-1-365(C) (2006), provides in part:

Except as provided in Section 56-5-2990, if the defendant surrendered his license to the magistrate or clerk immediately after conviction, the effective date of the revocation or suspension is the date of surrender. Â If the magistrate or clerk wilfully fails to forward the license and ticket to the department within five days, the suspension or revocation does not begin until the department receives and processes the license and ticket.

The trial court made only two findings of fact: Â that the clerk of court â€œdid not wilfully fail to forward [Dismukeâ€™s] license and ticket to the [D]epartment within five (5) daysâ€ and that Dismukeâ€™s suspension began on February 18, 2002 and ended on February 18, 2004.Â  The trial court viewed section 56-5-2990(F) as controlling.Â  We agree.
Absent a finding that Dismuke did not surrender his driverâ€™s license â€œimmediately after [his] convictionâ€ upon his plea of guilty and absent a finding that the clerk of court â€œwilfully fail[ed] to forward the licenseâ€ to the Department, â€œthe driverâ€™s license suspension period[ ]â€ in question â€œbeg[an] on the date [he] . . . receive[d] sentence upon a plea of guiltyâ€; i.e., February 18, 2002.
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We do not address the Departmentâ€™s second issue regarding whether Dismuke â€œowesâ€ nearly five months suspension time to the State.Â  Dismuke testified he obtained another driverâ€™s license on September 25, 2003, following his release on June 19, 2003, from federal prison after fourteen months imprisonment for a parole violation.Â  The Department first raised the issue of extending Dismukeâ€™s suspension in the court below during oral argument at the close of the case.Â  Although the trial court acknowledged in its oral remarks that Dismukeâ€™s suspension ended on February 18, 2004, without regard to the license that Dismuke obtained in 2003, the trial court never addressed in its written order the effect of Dismukeâ€™s obtaining another license some five months before his period of suspension ended.Â  See Elam v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 602 S.E.2d 772 (2004) (noting an issue must be both raised to and ruled on by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review); cf. Owens v. Magill, 308 S.C. 556, 564, 419 S.E.2d 786, 791 (1992) (â€œ[A] judge was not bound by a prior oral ruling and could issue a written order which conflicted with the prior oral ruling.â€).Â  In addition, the Department did not ask the court to address the issue in a motion to alter or amend its judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  Without an express ruling on this issue, we are powerless to review it.Â  See Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991) (holding the court of appeals should not address an issue that the â€œcircuit court did not explicitly rule onâ€ and was not the subject of a Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion to amend or alter the judgment).Â  
[2] Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3]Â  Testimony given by a clerk of court employee indicated an in-office audit led to the discovery of Dismukeâ€™s ticket in 2005.Â  The witness blamed a computer coding error and a change in the case management system for the failure to report Dismukeâ€™s conviction to the Department.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The Commissioners of Public Works, City of Charleston and North Charleston Sewer District, Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4186
Heard October 11, 2006 â€“ Filed December 18, 2006
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled January 23, 2007

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, 
VACATED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        CarlisleÂ  Roberts, Jr. and Jacquelyn Sue Dickman, both of Columbia and Evander Whitehead, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Frank Paul Calamita, III, of Richmond and Mary D. Shahid and Lucas C. Padgett, Jr., both of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  The South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order finding DHEC erred in imposing certain flow and load limits in permits issued to the Charleston Commissioners of Public Works and the North Charleston Sewer District (hereinafter â€œRespondentsâ€).Â Â  For the reasons discussed below, we affirm in part, reverse in part, vacate in part, and remand to the circuit court for the purpose of remanding to the DHEC Board.Â  
I.
Respondents collect and treat wastewater for portions of Charleston and Berkeley counties.Â  The treated wastewater, called effluent, is discharged into either the Cooper River or Charleston Harbor.Â  This discharge is permitted, subject to National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permits issued by DHEC.Â  In February 2003, DHEC issued Respondents renewed NPDES permits.Â  Respondents requested a contested case hearing to challenge various provisions of the renewed permits.Â  
Respondents challenged the renewed permits in two respects.Â  First, Respondents argued there was no factual or legal basis for DHEC to impose weekly and monthly volumetric effluent flow limits (flow limits) in the renewed permits.Â  Second, Respondents argued there was no factual or legal basis for DHEC to impose ultimate oxygen demand (UOD) load limits in the renewed permits.Â  The UOD load limits set forth in the renewed permits vary depending on the time of the year; the limits set for the months of November through February (â€œwinter monthsâ€) are approximately three times higher than the limits set for the months of March through October.[1] 
The UOD load limits were based upon a Total Maximum Daily Load (TMDL) established by DHEC.[2]Â  The TMDL purports to implement regulation 61-68(D)(4)(a) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005), a regulation known as the â€œ0.1 Rule.â€Â  The â€œ0.1 Ruleâ€ prohibits the quality of surface water from being cumulatively lowered more than 0.1 mg/l for dissolved oxygen from point sources and other activities when natural conditions cause a depression of dissolved oxygen.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 61-68(D)(4)(a) (Supp. 2005).Â  Respondents argued DHEC has no authority to apply UOD load limits during a given month in which there is no evidence of a depression of dissolved oxygen in the Cooper River or Charleston Harbor system for that month.Â  Specifically, Respondents challenged the imposition of lower UOD load limits during March, April, May, and October (the â€œshoulder monthsâ€).[3]Â  DHEC sought to justify the imposition of UOD load limits for the â€œshoulder monthsâ€ on a predictive modeling analysisâ€”a holistic approach that does not narrowly depend on the data for a specific month to warrant UOD load limits for that month.
The Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) affirmed the issuance of the permits subject to two modifications.Â  First, the ALJ ordered DHEC to remove the flow limits.Â  The ALJ found DHEC lacked the authority to impose flow limits in an NPDES permit, concluding neither the South Carolina Code nor DHEC regulations authorize imposition of flow limits. Further, the ALJ found that, under the facts of this case, flow limits were unnecessary to protect water quality.Â  
Second, the ALJ ordered DHEC to remove the UOD load limits set for the â€œshoulder months.â€Â  The ALJ adopted Respondentsâ€™ view and held the â€œ0.1 Ruleâ€ does not apply to the â€œshoulder monthsâ€ because there is no evidence of a depression in dissolved oxygen levels attributable to a natural condition during these months.Â  The ALJ thus concluded that the â€œ0.1 Ruleâ€ is only applicable during months in which such a depression is exhibited.Â  The ALJ determined the UOD load limits established for the â€œwinter monthsâ€ should also apply to the â€œshoulder months.â€Â  The ALJ further found DHEC was not authorized to rely on the TMDL to set permit limits because the TMDL was not promulgated as a regulation. 
DHEC appealed the ALJâ€™s order to the DHEC Board (the Board).Â  Citing the South Carolina Pollution Control Act (SCPCA), S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 48-1-10 to -350 (1987 and Supp. 2005), and regulation 61-9 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005), the Board first held DHEC has the â€œlegal authority to require flow limits in NPDES permits.â€Â  The Board, however, joined the ALJ in concluding effluent flow limits were not warranted on the facts presented in this case.Â  Accordingly, the Board affirmed the removal of the flow limits. 
The Board next held the ALJ erred in interpreting the â€œ0.1 Ruleâ€ as a matter of law.Â  The Board construed the statute and regulation as follows: â€œIf a waterbody is found to be a â€˜naturally dissolved oxygen waterbodyâ€™ for some period during the year, the requirements of Code Â§48-1-83 and related Regulation 61-68.D.4 apply.â€Â  Thus, contrary to the ALJâ€™s narrow interpretation that DHEC may only impose UOD load limits during the months a depression in dissolved oxygen levels is exhibited, the Board ruled the UOD load limits may be imposed any time during the year provided the â€œ0.1 Ruleâ€ is triggered at some point in the year.Â  Because DHEC did not appeal the ALJâ€™s finding that the TMDL was improperly relied on to establish UOD load limits, the Board remanded the permits to DHEC to establish UOD load limits without relying on the TMDL.[4] 
Respondents appealed to the circuit court.Â  Regarding the effluent flow limits (which had been ordered removed from the challenged permits), the circuit court proceeded to address the legal issue of whether DHEC has authority to impose effluent flow limits in NPDES permits.Â  The circuit court ruled DHEC lacks any express authority, either in statute or regulation, to impose flow limits.Â  The circuit court also held that â€œwhile the Board ordered the removal [sic] flow limits from the [Respondentsâ€™] permits, those limits have not been removed and the issue of the Boardâ€™s authority to impose flow limits is justiciable nevertheless because it is capable of repetition.â€
The circuit court agreed with Respondentsâ€™ legal claim that section 48-1-83 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) and regulation 61-68(D)(4)(a)â€”regarding the â€œ0.1 Ruleâ€â€”were unambiguous.Â  Although the statute and the regulation are silent as to when the â€œ0.1 Ruleâ€ may be applied, the circuit court ruled the law only allows the imposition of UOD load limits for a particular month when dissolved oxygen levels in a waterbody fall below the standard for that month.Â  As a result, the circuit court found the Board erred in remanding Respondentsâ€™ permits to DHEC staff for the purpose of calculating UOD loads for the â€œshoulder months.â€Â  The circuit court reversed the Board and reinstated the ALJâ€™s order.Â  This appeal followed.
II.
The ALJ presides over all hearings of contested DHEC permitting cases and, in such cases, serves as the finder of fact.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-600(B) (Act No. 387, 2006 S.C. Acts 387, eff. July 1, 2006); see also Brown v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 507, 520, 560 S.E.2d 410, 417 (2002).Â  The Board, pursuant to section 1-23-610(D) of the South Carolina Code (2005), reviewed the ALJâ€™s order.[5]Â  On appeal of such a contested case, a reviewing tribunal â€œmust affirm the ALJ if the findings are supported by substantial evidence, not based on the [reviewing tribunalâ€™s] own view of the evidence.â€Â  Dorman v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 350 S.C 159, 166, 565 S.E.2d. 119, 123 (Ct. App. 2002); Â§ 1-23-610(D).Â  The circuit court conducted the second appellate review under section 1-23-380(A)(6) of the South Carolina Code (2005).[6]
Our review of the circuit court, which constitutes the third appellate review, is also governed by section 1-23-380(A)(6).Â  Accordingly, this court may reverse the ALJâ€™s decision if substantial rights of the appellant have been prejudiced and the findings, inferences, conclusions or decisions (1) violate constitutional or statutory provisions, (2) exceed the statutory authority of the agency, (3) are based upon unlawful procedure, (4) are affected by other error of law, (5) are clearly erroneous in light of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the entire record, or (6) are either arbitrary, capricious, or reflect abuse of discretion or the obvious unwarranted exercise of discretion.Â  Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6); Weaver v. S.C. Coastal Council, 309 S.C. 368, 374, 423 S.E.2d 340, 343 (1992).Â Â Â Â  Â 
Â Under our standard of review, we may not substitute our judgment for that of the ALJ as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact unless the ALJâ€™s findings are clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence in the whole record.Â  See Marlboro Park Hosp. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 358 S.C. 573, 580, 595 S.E.2d 851, 855 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Substantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, but evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the agency reached.Â  Leventis v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 340 S.C. 118, 130, 530 S.E.2d 643, 650 (Ct. App. 2000). 
III.
DHEC contends the circuit court erred in finding Respondents adequately preserved issues for appeal because Respondentsâ€™ Petition for Judicial Review (petition) failed to properly raise the issues for consideration.Â  We disagree.Â  Having carefully reviewed the petition, we find it adequately apprised the circuit court of â€œthe abuse or abuses allegedly committed below through a distinct and specific statement of the rulings complained of.â€Â  Smith v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 284 S.C. 469, 471, 327 S.E.2d 348, 349 (1985).Â  Because the issues were sufficiently preserved in the appeal to the circuit court, we now turn to the merits.Â  
IV.
DHEC alleges the circuit court erred in rejecting the Boardâ€™s interpretation of the â€œ0.1 Ruleâ€ and finding the rule may only be applied during the months in which a natural depression in dissolved oxygen levels is demonstrated.Â  DHEC argues the regulation is ambiguous and, therefore, the Boardâ€™s interpretation is entitled to deference.Â  We agree.Â Â Â  
Generally, â€œthe construction of a statute by the agency charged with its administration will be accorded the most respectful consideration and will not be overruled absent compelling reasons.â€Â  Brown v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 507, 515, 560 S.E.2d 410, 414 (2002) (quoting Dunton v. S.C. Bd. of Examâ€™rs in Optometry, 291 S.C. 221, 223, 353 S.E.2d 132, 133 (1987)).Â  Indeed, the courts will typically defer to agency interpretation.Â  Id. at 515, 560 S.E.2d at 415.Â  
We note, however, â€œ[t]he primary rule of statutory construction is that the Court must ascertain the intention of the legislature.â€Â  Cooper v. Moore, 351 S.C. 207, 212, 569 S.E.2d 330, 332 (2002).Â  Moreover, where the terms of the statute are clear, the court must apply those terms according to their literal meaning, without resort to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation.Â  Moody v. Dairyland Ins. Co., 354 S.C. 28, 30-31, 579 S.E.2d 527, 529 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Thus, the court will reject the agencyâ€™s interpretation where it is specifically contrary to the statute or regulation.Â  Brown, 348 S.C. at 515, 560 S.E.2d at 415. Â 
Section 48-1-83(A) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005), the controlling statute of the â€œ0.1 Rule,â€ provides:

  [DHEC] shall not allow a depression in dissolved oxygen concentration greater than 0.10 mg/l in a naturally low dissolved oxygen waterbody unless the requirements of this section are all satisfied by demonstrating that resident aquatic species shall not be adversely affected.Â  The provisions of this section apply in addition to any standards for a dissolved oxygen depression in a naturally low dissolved oxygen waterbody promulgated by [DHEC] by regulation.

Regulation 61-68(D)(4) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005), drafted pursuant to the authority granted by the SCPCA, provides: 

  Certain natural conditions may cause a depression of dissolved oxygen in surface waters while existing and classified uses are still maintained. Â The Department shall allow a dissolved oxygen depression in these naturally low dissolved oxygen waterbodies as prescribed below pursuant to the Act, Section 48-1-83, et seq., 1976 Code of Laws:
  a. Under these conditions the quality of the surface waters shall not be cumulatively lowered more than 0.1 mg/l for dissolved oxygen from point sources and other activities . . . .

We find the statute and regulation are ambiguous as to when the â€œ0.1 Ruleâ€ applies.Â  Clearly, the regulation requires the quality of the surface waters â€œnot be cumulatively lowered more than 0.1 mg/l for dissolved oxygen from point sources or other activitiesâ€ when â€œ[c]ertain natural conditions . . . cause a depression of dissolved oxygen . . . .â€Â  Id.Â  The regulation is silent, however, as to the timing of the limitationsâ€™ application and allows for multiple interpretations.Â  DHEC asserts, for example, that the â€œ0.1 Ruleâ€ may be applied year-round whenever natural conditions cause a depression of dissolved oxygen in a waterbody at some point during the year.Â  
There is support for DHECâ€™s position in the record before us.Â  Larry Turner, manager of the Water Quality Modeling section for DHEC, testified that DHEC developed loadings that are protective and conservative.Â  He explained that during the four winter months (not at issue), DHEC determined less restrictive limits are required based on a number of factors including the cold weather and the increased ability of the system to absorb a pollutant without violating the standard during that period of the year.Â  For the remainder of the year, DHEC applied the â€œ0.1 Ruleâ€ as a protective measure given that the four summer months have a clearly demonstrated need for the â€œ0.1 Rule.â€ Â 
We appreciate Respondentsâ€™ desire that we find the statute and regulation mandate a monthly justification for the imposition of UOD load limits for a given month.Â  There is, however, no language in the statute or regulation that suggests DHEC is confined to a narrow examination of a particular monthâ€™s testing results to justify the application of the â€œ0.1 Ruleâ€ for that month.Â  
We find the statute is ambiguous and, therefore, defer to the Boardâ€™s interpretation.Â  See S.C. Coastal Conservation League v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 363 S.C. 67, 75, 610 S.E.2d 482, 486 (2005) (â€œCourts defer to the relevant administrative agencyâ€™s decisions with respect to its own regulations unless there is a compelling reason to differ.â€); see also Dunton v. S.C. Bd. of Examâ€™rs in Optometry, 291 S.C. 221, 223, 353 S.E.2d 132, 133 (1987) (â€œThe construction of a statute by the agency charged with its administration will be accorded the most respectful consideration and will not be overruled absent compelling reasons.â€).Â  
We find no compelling reasons to overrule the Boardâ€™s interpretation as it is neither arbitrary nor capricious, and does not constitute an abuse of discretion.Â  Further, Larry Turnerâ€™s testimony provides a sound basis for why DHEC would take a holistic approach (and not a myopic month-to-month analysis) in evaluating when reasonable UOD load limits in a naturally dissolved oxygen waterbody are warranted.Â  Admittedly, UOD load limits are issued in monthly intervals, but the decision whether to impose UOD load limits in a given month is not restricted to testing data for that month.Â  
We find the Boardâ€™s interpretation of the â€œ0.1 Ruleâ€â€”the statute and regulation it is charged with enforcingâ€”is reasonable and in line with its overall statutory mandate.Â  We hold the circuit court erred in reversing the Board and adopt the Boardâ€™s finding that when natural conditions cause a depression of dissolved oxygen in a waterbody at some point during the year the â€œ0.1 Ruleâ€ may be applied.Â Â Â Â  
V.
DHEC asserts the circuit court erred in reversing the Boardâ€™s remand of the renewed permits for a determination of the applicable UOD load limits for the â€œshoulder months.â€Â  We agree.Â  
Initially, we note the procedural posture of this case is awkward and confusing.Â  Respondents acknowledge decreased UOD load limits apply during the critical summer months and only challenge the imposition of the lower limits during the â€œshoulder months.â€Â  The ALJ found DHEC improperly relied on the TMDL to establish UOD load limits and this ruling was not challenged by DHEC.Â  Thus, while DHEC used the TMDL to establish the renewed permit conditions for the entire year, DHEC is barred in connection with these permits from using the TMDL to establish limits for the â€œshoulder months.â€Â  As a result, the Board, after finding the â€œ0.1 Ruleâ€ may be applied year-round, remanded the renewed permits to DHEC to allow UOD load limits to be imposed during the â€œshoulder monthsâ€ without relying on the TMDL.Â  Yet, the TMDL was used to determine the limits for the other months.Â  
Nevertheless, pursuant to section 1-23-610(D) of the South Carolina Code (2005), the Board has authority to remand a case for further proceedings.Â  Because we defer to DHECâ€™s interpretation of the application of the â€œ0.1 Rule,â€ we necessarily reinstate the Boardâ€™s remand of the permits to DHEC.Â  DHEC must be given the opportunity to establish UOD load limits for the â€œshoulder monthsâ€ without relying on the TMDL.Â  
VI.
DHEC alleges the circuit court erred in finding DHEC does not have the authority to impose flow limits in an NPDES permit.Â  We decline to address this legal issue because any ruling issued by this court would be merely advisory. 
It is unchallenged that there is no factual basis for flow limits in the subject NPDES permits.Â  The ALJ ordered DHEC to remove the flow limits from the renewed permits, and the Board affirmed this ruling.Â  DHEC did not appeal the removal of the flow limits from the NPDES permits.Â  Therefore, this is the law of the case.Â  Ulmer v. Ulmer, 369 S.C. 486, __, 632 S.E.2d 858, 861 (2006) (â€œA portion of a judgment that is not appealed presents no issue for determination by the reviewing court and constitutes, rightly or wrongly, the law of the case.â€) (quoting Austin v. Specialty Transp. Servs., 358 S.C. 298, 320, 594 S.E.2d 867, 878 (Ct. App. 2004)).
The only issue concerning flow limits addressed and decided by the circuit court was whether DHEC has the legal authority to impose the flow limits.Â  The circuit court erred in addressing this issue.Â  Determining whether DHEC is authorized to include flow limits in an NPDES permit will have no impact on a party in a case where flow limits have been ordered to be removed from the renewed permits.Â  We hold DHECâ€™s inability to enforce the flow limits based on the unchallenged factual findings makes any opinion regarding DHECâ€™s authority to impose flow limits advisory.Â  Accordingly, this court will not address the issue.[7]Â  See Binkley v. Rabon Creek Watershed Conservation Dist. of Fountain Inn, 348 S.C. 58, 76 n.36, 558 S.E.2d 902, 911 n.36 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œThis court will not issue advisory opinions that have no practical effect on the outcome.â€); see also In re Chance, 277 S.C. 161, 161, 284 S.E.2d 231, 231 (1981) (noting South Carolina appellate courts have â€œconsistently refrainedâ€ from issuing purely advisory opinions).
VII.
We find (1) the Boardâ€™s interpretation of the application of the â€œ0.1 Ruleâ€ is entitled to deference because the statute and regulation are ambiguous; (2) the Boardâ€™s remand of the renewed permits to allow DHEC to determine the UOD load limits for the â€œshoulder monthsâ€ without relying on the TMDL was proper; and (3) the circuit court erred in deciding the issue of whether DHEC has the authority to impose flow limits in an NPDES permit because the issue is not in controversy.Â  Moreover, to the extent the issue of DHECâ€™s legal authority to impose effluent flow limits was addressed below, all legal conclusions are vacated.Â  The Boardâ€™s order should be reinstated except for the finding regarding DHECâ€™s authority to impose flow limits.Â  
The decision of the circuit court is accordingly
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, VACATED IN PART, and REMANDED.
STILWELL and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Higher UOD limits are easier for Respondents to meet; lower UOD limits are more restrictive and, therefore, more difficult for Respondents to meet.Â  
[2]Â  DHECâ€™s Exhibit 6 provides this description of the TMDL process: â€œThe TMDL process establishes the allowable loading of pollutants or other quantifiable parameters for a waterbody based on the relationship between pollution sources and instream water quality conditions, so that the states can establish water quality based controls to reduce pollution from both point and non-point sources and restore and maintain the quality of their water resources.â€Â  
[3]Â  Respondents raised an additional issue at the contested case hearing regarding whether requirements for whole effluent toxicity testing were properly included in the permits.Â  The testing requirements were found proper and this finding was not challenged on appeal.Â  
[4]Â  DHEC did not challenge the ALJâ€™s rejection of the TMDL.Â  The Board, sitting in an appellate capacity, was thus bound by the ALJâ€™s determination in this regard.Â  We further note that DHECâ€™s decision to impose, or not to impose, UOD load limits for eight months of the year (other than the â€œshoulder monthsâ€) was not challenged, although the TMDL served as the basis for DHECâ€™s permitting decisions. 
[5]Â  Section 1-23-610(D) was amended by Act No. 387, 2006 S.C. Acts 387; however, the applicable language at all times pertinent to the present appeal is found in section 1-23-610(D) of the South Carolina Code (2005).Â  Pursuant to the amendment, effective July 1, 2006, DHEC administrative appeals will no longer track the awkward path followed here where the DHEC Board sits in an appellate capacity and applies the substantial evidence standard of review under the Administrative Procedures Act.Â  See Marlboro Park Hosp. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 358 S.C. 573, 577, 595 S.E.2d 851, 853 (Ct. App. 2004) (outlining the DHEC Boardâ€™s standard of review prior to the 2006 amendment). 
[6]Â  This section was also amended by Act No. 387, 2006 S.C. Acts 387; however, as above, the applicable language at all times pertinent to the present appeal is found in section 1-23-380(A)(6) of the South Carolina Code (2005).Â  
[7]Â  Our decision not to address this issue is further supported by the uncertain circumstances surrounding it.Â  If DHEC has the authority to impose flow limits in NPDES permits, as it contends, DHEC has done nothing required to promulgate this authority into a regulation.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-1-30 (1987) (providing that DHEC is required to promulgate regulations to implement the SCPCA); see also Sloan v. S.C. Bd. of Physical Therapy Examâ€™rs, Op. No. 26209 (S.C. Sup. Ct. Filed Sept. 25, 2006) (Shearouse Ad. Sh. No. 36 at 46) (â€œIn order to promulgate a regulation, the APA generally requires a state agency to give notice of a drafting period during which public comments are accepted on a proposed regulation; conduct a public hearing on the proposed regulation overseen by an administrative law judge or an agencyâ€™s governing board; possibly prepare reports about the regulationâ€™s impact on the economy, environment, and public health; and submit the regulation to the Legislature for review, modification, and approval or rejection.â€) (citing S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 1-23-110 to -160 (2005 and Supp. 2005)).Â  Conversely, DHEC argues it can apply flow limits as it chooses because its action does not establish a â€œbinding norm.â€Â  Yet, DHEC has provided this court with no standard setting forth the conditions under which DHEC will impose the flow limits.
