THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Richard Kimmer, Respondent,
v.
Murata of America, Inc. and Liberty Mutual Insurance Company,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal from Chester County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4187
Heard December 5, 2006 â€“ Filed December 18, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
Pope D. Johnson, III, of Columbia, for Appellants.
Thomas H. Pope, of Newberry, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation action, Richard Kimmer sought benefits for an alleged work injury.Â  Before filing his workersâ€™ compensation claim and without notifying his employer-carrier (collectively Murata), Kimmer settled a third party claim for the liability policy limit.Â  The single commissioner concluded Kimmer elected his remedy by failing to notify Murata, and his workersâ€™ compensation claim was barred.Â  The Appellate Panel adopted the single commissionerâ€™s conclusion.Â  Kimmer appealed to the circuit court, which reversed the Appellate Panel and awarded Kimmer total disability benefits.Â  We reverse.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On January 29, 1999, Kimmer sustained injuries in a motor vehicle accident as he was driving to work for his employer, Murata. Â The driver at fault was Anthony Pendergrass. As a result of the accident, Kimmer was diagnosed with meniscal tears in both knees, a ruptured disc at L4-5, post-traumatic stress syndrome and depression.Â Â Â  Following the accident, Kimmer had three surgeries on his right knee and one surgery on his left knee.Â  
Pendergrass had automobile liability insurance with a policy limit of $15,000. Following the accident and without notice to Murata, Kimmer negotiated a settlement of the third party claim with Pendergrassâ€™ liability carrier for the policy limit. Â On June 16, 1999, Kimmer signed a release of all claims against Pendergrass. Â 
Kimmer filed a Form 50 on June 18, 1999, and an Amended Form 50 on May 29, 2002, seeking workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  On June 18, 2002, Murata filed its Form 51 denying Kimmerâ€™s claim and asserting as a defense that the third party action had been settled without consent.Â  On December 10, 2002, a hearing was held to determine the issues set forth in the Forms 50 and 51.Â  The single commissioner found Kimmerâ€™s injuries compensable because Murata provided him with a car allowance and mileage.Â  However, she denied Kimmerâ€™s claim. Relying on Fisher v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Mental Retardation-Coastal Ctr., 277 S.C. 573, 291 S.E.2d 200 (1982), the single commissioner concluded the settlement of the third party claim, without notice to Murata, constituted an election of remedies and barred the workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  
The Appellate Panel affirmed and adopted the order of the single commissioner.Â Â  On appeal to the circuit court, the trial judge (1) reversed the order of the Appellate Panel, (2) awarded total and permanent disability to Kimmer, (3) awarded Murata an offset of $10,000 (the net amount of the third party settlement), and (4) entered judgment in favor of Kimmer in the amount of $209,235.00.Â  
On July 25, 2005, Murata filed a Motion for Reconsideration.Â  The circuit court issued an amended order reversing the order of the Appellate Panel and finding that (1) Murata suffered no prejudice as a result of the settlement without notice, (2) Kimmer was totally and permanently disabled, and (3) Kimmer was entitled to an award of total and permanent disability, less an offset for the third party settlement.Â  Murata then filed a Motion to Reconsider arguing the circuit court erroneously inserted a prejudice requirement into workersâ€™ compensation cases involving election of remedies. Â The motion was denied on September 1, 2005. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW 
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard for judicial review of workersâ€™ compensation commission decisions.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981); Bass v. Isochem, 365 S.C. 454, 467, 617 S.E.2d 369, 376 (Ct. App. 2005) cert. granted, November 2, 2006; Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C. 276, 288, 599 S.E.2d 604, 610 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  A reviewing court may reverse or modify an agency decision if the findings, inferences, conclusions, or decisions of that agency are â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€ Bass v. Kenco Group, 366 S.C. 450, 457, 622 S.E.2d 577, 580 (Ct. App. 2005); Bursey v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 360 S.C. 135, 141, 600 S.E.2d 80, 84 (Ct. App. 2004); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Act No. 387, 2006 S.C. Acts 387, eff. July 1, 2006). Under the scope of review established in the APA, this court may not substitute its judgment for that of the Appellate Panel as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â Â 
Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. S.C. Second Injury Fund, 363 S.C. 612, 619, 611 S.E.2d 297, 300 (Ct. App. 2005); Frame v. Resort Servs., Inc., 357 S.C. 520, 527, 593 S.E.2d 491, 495 (Ct. App. 2004); Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 337, 478 S.E.2d 74, 76 (Ct. App. 1996); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Act No. 387, 2006 S.C. Acts 387, eff. July 1, 2006).
An administrative agencyâ€™s findings are presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.Â 
Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 492, 541 S.E.2d 526, 528 (2001); Hicks v. Piedmont Cold Storage, Inc., 335 S.C. 46, 48, 515 S.E.2d 532, 533 (1999); Gadson v. Mikasa Corp., 368 S.C. 214, 222, 628 S.E.2d 262, 266 (Ct. App. 2006).Â 
Accordingly, a reviewing court may not substitute its judgment for that of the Appellate Panel as to the weight of the evidence on questions
of fact. Â Stephen, 324 S.C. at 337, 478 S.E.2d at 76. It is not within our province to reverse findings of the Appellate Panel which are supported by substantial evidence. Â Broughton v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 496, 520 S.E.2d 634, 637 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Instead, review of issues of fact is limited to determining whether the findings are supported by substantial evidence in the record. Â Hargrove, 360 S.C. at 289, 599 S.E.2d at 610-11.Â  â€œOn appeal, this court must affirm an award of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission in which the circuit court concurred if substantial evidence supports the findings.â€Â  Solomon v. W.B. Easton, Inc., 307 S.C. 518, 520, 415 S.E.2d 841, 843 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  Substantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the administrative agency reached in order to justify its action.Â  Pratt v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 622, 594 S.E.2d 272, 274 (2004); Jones v. Georgia-Pacific Corp., 355 S.C. 413, 417, 586 S.E.2d 111, 113 (2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The circuit court held Kimmerâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation action was not barred by his third party settlement, but only subject to an offset for the third party settlement he received.Â  Murata contends this holding was error because Kimmer settled his third party claim without notice to Murata, thereby electing his remedy.Â  We agree.Â  
The South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act provides claimants with three remedies for job-related injuries:


  (1) Pursuant to section 42-1-560 (c) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) a claimant may proceed solely against the employer, thereby allowing the employer-carrier the opportunity to pursue reimbursement against the third party for its obligated payments: 
  
If, prior to the expiration of the one-year period referred to in subsection (b), or within thirty days prior to the expiration of the time in which such action may be brought, the injured employee . . . shall not have commenced action against or settled with the third party, the right of action of the injured employee . . . shall pass by assignment to the carrier; provided, that the assignment shall not occur less than twenty days after the carrier has notified the injured employee . . . in writing, by personal service or by registered or certified mail that failure to commence such action will operate as an assignment of the cause of action to the carrier.
  

  (2) Alternatively, a claimant may proceed solely against the third party tortfeasor under section 42-1-550 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) by instituting and prosecuting an action at law:
  
When an employee, his personal representative or other person may have a right to recover damages for injury, loss of service or death from any person other than the employer, he may institute an action at law against such third person before an award is made under this Title [Workersâ€™ Compensation Act] and prosecute it to its final determination.
  

  (3) Or a claimant may proceed against both the employer-carrier and the third party tortfeasor by complying with section 42-1-560 (b) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005):

The injured employee . . . shall be entitled to receive the compensation and other benefits provided by this Title [Workersâ€™ Compensation Act] and to enforce by appropriate proceedings his or their rights against the third party . . . . In such case the carrier shall have a lien on the proceeds of any recovery from the third party whether by judgment, settlement or otherwise, to the extent of the total amount of compensation, including medical and other expenses, paid, or to be paid by such carrier, less the reasonable and necessary expenses, including attorney fees, incurred in effecting the recovery, and to the extent the recovery shall be deemed to be for the benefit of the carrier . . . . Notice of the commencement of the action shall be given within thirty days thereafter to the Industrial Commission, the employer and carrier upon a form prescribed by the Industrial Commission. 


See Fisher v. S. C. Depâ€™t of Mental Retardation, 277 S.C. 573, 575, 291 S.E.2d 200, 201 (1982) (emphasis added). 
I.Â  Notice

The imperative nature of the statutory language mandating notice of a third party claim to the employer-carrier is well established by our precedent.Â  In 1982, our Supreme Court announced that a claimant who settled his third party case without notice to the employer or carrier elected his remedy and waived any right to workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  Fisher, 277 S.C. at 576, 291 S.E.2d at 201. Â As in the instant case, Fisher sought workersâ€™ compensation benefits after making a compromise settlement with a third party tortfeasor without the consent of the carrier. Â The single commissioner, Appellate Panel, and circuit court agreed Fisher had elected to proceed against a third party without complying with section 42-1-560 and, having done so, had no further remedy under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  Noting section 42-1-560 (b) does not specifically state the consequences of failure to notify the employer-carrier of a third party claim or settlement, the court emphasized, â€œit is clear from a reading of the statute that the legislature did not intend for a claimant to settle his third party case without regard to the employerâ€™s rights for subrogation under Â§ 42-1-560 and still maintain a workmenâ€™s compensation claim.â€ Â Fisher, 277 S.C. at 575, 291 S.E.2d at 201. Â The Fisher court reiterated an earlier observation that â€œ[t]he object of Â§ 42-1-560 is to effect an equitable adjustment of the rights of all the parties.â€ Â Stroy v. Millwood Drug Store, Inc., 235 S.C. 52, ___, 109 S.E.2d 706, 709 (1959). Drawing from its analysis in a case decided under prior statutes, the court recognized â€œ[i]t would â€˜defeat this objective to allow the employee to demand compensation from the employer after having destroyed the employerâ€™s normal right to obtain reimbursement from the third party.â€™ â€ Id. at 575-76, 291 S.E.2d at 201(quoting Stroy, 235 S.C. 52, 109 S.E.2d at 709).Â  
The South Carolina Supreme Court reaffirmed the principle articulated in Fisher when it addressed a dilemma generated by asbestos claims.Â  In Talley v. John-Mansville Sales Corp., workersâ€™ instituted product liability actions against asbestos manufacturers. 285 S.C. 117, 118, 328 S.E.2d 621, 622 (1985).Â  The workers sought to have the asbestos manufacturersâ€™ settlement offers approved by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission in order to comply with section 42-1-560 and protect their potential workersâ€™ compensation claims. Â Id. at 118, 328 S.E.2d at 622.Â  The Commission refused to approve the settlements, ruling it had no jurisdiction because the workers had not yet become disabled.Â  Id. Â Consequently, the workers applied for a stay of the civil actions, which the circuit judge denied.Â  Id. at 119, 328 S.E.2d at 623.Â  Our Supreme Court reversed the denial, explaining: â€œ[h]ad [the workers] concluded their product liability actions, by settlement or otherwise, they would have made a binding election of remedies under Fisher v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Mental Retardation, 277 S.C. 573, 291 S.E.2d 200 (1982), and would be barred from pursuing benefits under workersâ€™ compensation at a later date.â€ Â Talley, 285 S.C at 118, 328 S.E.2d at 622.Â  On the other hand, if the workers waited until they became disabled for workersâ€™ compensation purposes, their third party actions would be barred by the statute of limitations. Â Id. Â The court declined to carve out an exception in the statute to accommodate these unusual circumstances, concluding:Â  â€œ[s]uch a change is a function of the legislature, and this court refuses to usurp legislative authority in this matter.â€Â  Id. at 119, 328 S.E.2d at 622. Â Instead, the court ordered entry of the stay to avoid the inequity that would result from the application of Fisher to the circumstances in Talley. Â Id. at 199, 3289 S.E.2s at 623, n. 2.
Subsequently, the Court of Appeals addressed the notice requirement in Johnson v. Pennsylvania Millers Mut. Ins. Co., 292 S.C. 33, 354 S.E.2d 791 (Ct. App. 1987) and Hudson v. Townsend Saw Chain Co., 296 S.C. 17, 370 S.E.2d 104 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  In Johnson, the claimant prosecuted his third party claim to an adverse conclusion. Â 292 S.C. at 34, 354 S.E.2d at 792. Â The single commissioner and Appellate Panel, relying on Fisher, agreed with Pennsylvania Millers that the claimant had elected his remedy and waived his right to compensation.Â  Id. at 34-5, 354 S.E.2d at 792.Â  The circuit court disagreed. Â Id. at 36, 354 S.E.2d at 796. Â On appeal, we distinguished Fisher as inapplicable in Johnson, because the claimant in Johnson did not settle the third party action; rather, he prosecuted the case to its full conclusion. Â Id. at 39, 354 S.E.2d 794. Â â€œIf [the claimant] had settled the third party action and had done so without Pennsylvania Millersâ€™ consent, the Supreme Courtâ€™s holding in Fisher would have barred him from thereafter pursuing a workersâ€™ compensation claim.â€ Â Id. (emphasis added) Â Neither the single commissioner nor the Appellate Panel had determined whether the claimant had complied with the notice requirements. Id. Consequently, we remanded to the Commission for that determination and emphasized if the claimant gave proper notice of the third party action, then he had not elected his remedy or waived his workersâ€™ compensation claim.

Neither Section 42-1-550, which allows an injured worker to maintain a third party action â€œbefore an award is made,â€ nor Section 42-1-560, which preserves an injured employeeâ€™s right to pursue a third party claim while also seeking workersâ€™ compensation, can be read to constitute, under the doctrine of election of remedies, a bar to an employee subsequently proceeding against the carrier once the action at law is prosecuted to a final, but unsuccessful, determination where the injured employee gave the carrier proper notice of the third party action.

Id. at 40, 354 S.E.2d at 795 (emphasis added). 
Â Hudson v. Townsend Saw Chain Co. illustrates the scope of the notice requirementâ€™s applicability. Â 296 S.C. 17, 21-22, 370 S.E.2d 104, 106 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  Hudson prosecuted a third-party claim to its conclusion, without issuing the required statutory notice. Id. The single commissioner and Appellate Panel found Hudson had elected her remedy and her workersâ€™ compensation claim was barred. Id. at 19, 370 S.E.2d at 105. The circuit court reversed, deeming the section 42-1-560(b) notice requirement inapplicable where an employee prosecutes the third-party claim to a final determination before filing for workersâ€™ compensation. The circuit court viewed section 42-1-560â€™s notice requirement applicable only to the situation in which an employee pursues a workersâ€™ compensation claim simultaneously with a third-party action. Â Id. at 19, 370 S.E.2d at 105-06.Â  In reversing the circuit court, we clarified:Â  

[I]rrespective of whether an employee pursues a third-party action before or simultaneously with filing a workersâ€™ compensation claim, the employee, to preserve his or her claim to workersâ€™ compensation, must provide the notice required by Section 42-1-560(b). If the employee fails to give the notice required by Section 42-1-560(b) and prosecutes the third-party action to a final determination, either before or simultaneously with filing a workersâ€™ compensation claim, the employee will be regarded as having elected his or her remedy and will be barred from receiving workersâ€™ compensation benefits.

Id. at 20-21, 370 S.E.2d at 106.
The undisputed facts of the instant case are nearly identical to those in Fisher.Â  Kimmer instituted his third party claim against a tortfeasor without notice to Murata.Â  Subsequently, he settled with the liability carrier and released the at-fault driver from all claims without Murataâ€™s consent. Â South Carolina appellate courts have conclusively held a claimant who pursues a third party action without giving proper notice to the employer-carrier and settles the third party action or pursues it to an unsuccessful conclusion is regarded as having elected his remedy and is barred from receiving workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s order, which awards Kimmer workersâ€™ compensation benefits, notwithstanding his failure to give the required notice to Murata, is inconsistent with our precedent.Â  As a result of Kimmerâ€™s noncompliance with the statutory procedure, he made an election of his remedy and waived any rights he may have had to recover workersâ€™ compensation benefits.
II.Â  Prejudice
Murata maintains the circuit court erred in determining Kimmerâ€™s failure to give timely notice of his third party claim did not prejudice Murata, and, consequently, did not bar Kimmerâ€™s recovery of workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  We agree with Murata.Â  
Contrary to Kimmerâ€™s suggestion, the mere mention of the word â€œprejudiceâ€ in an opinion does not mean that such a requirement exists. Neither section 42-1-550 nor section 42-1-560 contains a provision establishing prejudice as a factor in considering whether a compensation claim is barred when an employee settles or concludes a third party claim without notice. Â Moreover, our precedentâ€™s strong and unwavering emphasis on the importance of notice outweighs the relevance of prejudice in considering whether a workerâ€™s compensation claim is barred.Â  See Fisher v. S. C. Depâ€™t of Mental Retardation-Coastal Center, 277 S.C. 573, 291 S.E.2d 200 (1982); Talley v. John-Mansville Sales Corp., 285 S.C. 117, 328 S.E.2d 621, (1985); Johnson v. Pennsylvania Millers Mut. Ins. Co., 292 S.C. 33, 354 S.E.2d 791 (Ct. App. 1987); Hudson v. Townsend Saw Chain Co., 296 S.C. 17, 370 S.E.2d 104 (Ct. App. 1988). The Fisher court interpreted the implicated statutes but made no mention of a prejudice requirement. 277 S.C. at 573, 291 S.E.2d at 200. Â In Hudson, the claimant urged that a workersâ€™ compensation claim should be permitted if the carrier was not prejudiced by the lack of notice.Â  Hudson at 22, 370 S.E.2d at 107.Â  We declared: â€œHudsonâ€™s contention and the circuit courtâ€™s holding regarding lack of prejudice, however, is unpersuasive, if in fact the question of prejudice is relevant at all.â€ Â Id.; see Stroy v. Millwood Drug Store, Inc., 235 S.C. 52, ___, 109 S.E.2d 706, 709 (1959) (rejecting an almost identical argument made by a workersâ€™ compensation claimant in a case decided under former statutes).Â  Additionally, in Talley, our Supreme Court declined to carve out an exception to the statutes as interpreted by Fisher, regarding any such change as a function of the legislature, not the courts. 
As a result of the failure to notify of a third party claim, the employer-carrier loses a voice in the litigation and is clearly prejudiced. Â Stroy, 235 S.C. 52, 109 S.E.2d at 709.[1] That voice encompasses the right to select oneâ€™s own counsel, conduct oneâ€™s own investigation, and direct the litigation. Â See id. Â Notice makes it possible for the employer-carrier to offer the employee meaningful assistance in prosecuting the third party claim. Â Hudson, 296 S.C. at 22, 370 S.E.2d at 107.Â  With timely knowledge the employer-carrier gains the opportunity to lend support to an effort that could lead to the carrierâ€™s recovery of some or all of the compensation it might later be required to pay the injured employee under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act. Id.; see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-560 (c).Â  The statuteâ€™s underlying purpose serves to protect the carrierâ€™s subrogation interests and prevents an employeeâ€™s double recovery.Â  Â 
Hypothetically, if prejudice to the employer-carrier were required as an additional element to find the claimant elected his remedy, we identify prejudice to Murata in the instant case. 
The single commissionerâ€™s findings comport with our determination:

[T]he claimantâ€™s settling of this claim was prejudicial to the carrier since it [Murata] was not able to participate in the litigation or affect the full and final release executed by the claimant.Â  The carrier had no opportunity to investigate whether there was [sic] other assets or other coverage available to the claimant from the third party.

Kimmer avers his settlement for the liability policy limit is distinguishable from the â€œcompromiseâ€ settlement in Fisher because the at-fault party had no additional assets for Murata to pursue.Â  Though Kimmerâ€™s counsel determined the coverage under one liability policy and consulted Chester county records to discover any undisclosed assets, his investigation was by no means exhaustive.Â  In South Carolina, statutory provisions allow for the initiation and institution of supplementary proceedings.Â  Section 15-39-310 of the South Carolina Code (1976) provides: 

[T]he judgment creditor . . . is entitled to an order from a judge of the circuit court requiring such judgment debtor to appear and answer concerning his property before such judge at a time and place specified in the order within the county to which the execution was issued.Â  

At the hearing in regard to a supplementary proceeding, a prospective debtor is required to answer under oath all queries as to real and personal property, including, but not limited to, policies of insurance, cash, jewelry, household furniture, and the entire spectrum and gamut of legal ownership possibilities.Â  Additionally, a judgment obtained against a motorist that is unpaid subjects the motorist to driverâ€™s license suspension pursuant to section 56-9-430 of the South Carolina Code (1976).Â  Murataâ€™s right to avail itself of the full range of investigatory opportunities was foreclosed by the absence of notice of the third party claim.Â  Furthermore, as part of the third party settlement, Kimmer released the at-fault driver from all liability, extinguishing any recourse Murata may have had in pursuing third party assets. Â 
CONCLUSION
We rule that the settlement of a third party claim without notice to the employer and carrier bars a workersâ€™ compensation action.Â  We hold that prejudice is NOT an element to be considered in regard to the failure to give the mandated statutory notice.Â  Assumptively concluding that prejudice is a factor in the analysis, we conclude that there was actual prejudice in the case sub judice in regard to the employer and carrier. 
Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court is reversed and the order of the Appellate Panel reinstated.[2]Â  
REVERSED. 
HUFF and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Though this case was decided under the former statute, its discussion on what constitutes prejudice is instructive.Â  
[2] Because we reverse on the previous issue, we need not reach the additional issues.Â  See 
Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (â€œ[A]n appellate court need not address remaining issues when disposition of prior issue is dispositive.â€).

PREHEARING REPORT


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Deborah S. Davis, Respondent,
v.
James Kelly Davis, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Paul W. Garfinkel, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4188
Heard December 5, 2006 â€“ Filed December 21, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Michael David Wood, Patricia Oâ€™Neill DeTreville, and James Michael DeTreville, all of Charleston, for Appellant.
William J. Clifford, of North Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.: Â In this domestic action, James Kelly Davis (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s (1) awarding Deborah Davis (Wife) Â Â alimony and attorneyâ€™s fees; and (2) finding Husband in contempt for failure to comply with the family courtâ€™s orders concerning the distribution of personal property, payment of Wifeâ€™s equitable share of the marital home, harassment, and communication with Wife about the childrenâ€™s issues.Â  We affirm. 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Husband and Wife divorced on May 7, 2001 after almost twenty-one years of marriage.Â  The couple has three sons.
Wife is a college graduate.Â  At the time of the divorce she had worked in her fatherâ€™s insurance agency, primarily as the office manager, for approximately eleven years.Â  Father retired in December, 2001 and Wife began working as a library media specialist at a middle school for a yearly salary of $31,000. She anticipated a $2000 yearly salary increase upon completion of her masterâ€™s degree.Â  In addition, Wife intends to become certified by a national board, for which she expects a $7500 yearly increase in salary.Â  Her present income is supplemented with earnings from a part time job with Weight Watchers. 
When Father retired, Wifeâ€™s earnings from her work at Fatherâ€™s agency were near $85,000.Â  Wife testified her income was inflated as a result of the father-daughter relationship. Â She enjoyed a flexible work schedule and the use of a company car.Â  Father first mentioned his upcoming retirement in 1999, prior to Husband and Wifeâ€™s divorce. Â Husband and Wife planned for Fatherâ€™s impending retirement by starting a gift basket business called Baskets of Fun.Â  This venture was ultimately unsuccessful.Â Â  Â 
Wife explained that jobs available to her in the insurance industry would require extended periods of travel and would start at a salary of approximately $40,000 per year.Â  She estimated her services while working in Fatherâ€™s business were worth $50,000 a year to a comparable insurance agency. Â Â 
Husband formerly worked at Forsburg Engineering, where he earned an annual salary of $75,000, plus bonuses that brought his total yearly earnings to approximately $100,000.Â  Prior to Fatherâ€™s retirement, Husband left Forsburg and began a land surveying business, Absolute Surveying, in which he currently holds a thirty-five percent interest. Â On his financial declaration he indicated an annual salary of $51,000.Â  In addition to his salary, Absolute Surveying provided Husband with a car, car insurance and maintenance, gas, health insurance, health club, cable, and credit cards.Â  The family court determined the value of those benefits amounted to $1100 monthly. Partnership distributions from Absolute averaged $1,333.33 per month.Â  Husband had other real estate partnership interests which he failed to include on his financial declaration.Â  Those interests yielded $35,000 from the sale of real property in 2002 and reflected an average of $10,000 equity in each of ten (10) condominiums. 
The family court approved and adopted the partiesâ€™ agreement on â€œall issues arising from the marriage, save and except the issue of divorce,â€ in the March 12, 2001 divorce decree.Â  Terms of the agreement relevant to Husbandâ€™s appeal included a provision for joint legal custody of their three sons and the requirement that each party keep the other informed about matters concerning the children.Â  The litigants were restrained from harming, harassing, bothering or otherwise disturbing each other, whether at their respective residences, employment, or the like. Â The marital home would be the sole property of Husband and, for the purpose of equitable distribution, valued at $325,000. Â The home was to be refinanced to provide funds for Wifeâ€™s equitable share.Â  Husband was permitted to subtract from the $325,000 valuation of the home the first mortgage payoff, reasonably necessary closing costs, and the balance of Wifeâ€™s equity loan.Â  In addition, Husband was directed to pay Wife fifty percent of settlement proceeds from Forsberg Engineering no later than the refinance closing date. Wife was entitled to obtain from Husband certain items of personal property, and the parties were instructed to cooperate in the expeditious transfer of those items. Â The parties agreed to reserve the issue of alimony for a five year period, during which either party could assert a claim for alimony against the other.
Wife filed a complaint on December 10, 2001, and an amended complaint on February 19, 2002, seeking $1000 per month alimony.Â  During the pendency of this litigation Wife initiated a number of enforcement actions based on Husbandâ€™s non-compliance with the divorce decree. In its final ruling the family court awarded Wife $635 per month in alimony, adjusted to be retroactive from the date of the temporary hearing. Â In addition to noting its concern over the absence of Husbandâ€™s forthrightness regarding his income, the family court found Husband in contempt for failure to: (1) provide Wife with copies of family photographs, (2) pay Wife her equitable share of the marital home, (3) refrain from harassing Wife, and (4) Â Â communicate with Wife regarding issues with their children.Â  Wife was awarded attorneyâ€™s fees as well.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Nasser-Moghaddassi v. Moghaddassi, 364 S.C. 182, 189, 612 S.E.2d 707, 711 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Emery v. Smith, 361 S.C. 207, 213, 603 S.E.2d 598, 601 (Ct. App. 2004)).Â  Â However, this broad scope of review does not require this court to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Lacke v. Lacke, 362 S.C. 302, 307, 608 S.E.2d 147, 149 (Ct. â€œThe Family Court is authorized by statute to order payment of suit money, including attorney[â€™s] fees, to either party in a divorce action.â€Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 412, 415, 368 S.E.2d 901, 903 (1988).Â  Section 20-7-420(38) (Supp. 2005) of the South Carolina Code provides: â€œ[s]uit money, including attorneyâ€™s fees, may be assessed for or against a party to an action brought in or subject to the jurisdiction of the family court.â€
An award of attorneyâ€™s fees lies within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 553, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004); Bowen v Bowen, 327 S.C. 561, 563, 490 S.E.2d 271, 272, (Ct. App. 1997).Â  The family court, in determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, should consider each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fees, the beneficial results obtained, the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions, and the effect of the fee on the partiesâ€™ standards of living. Â E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  In determining the reasonable amount of attorneyâ€™s fees to award, the family court must take into account the nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered, the time necessarily devoted to the case, counselâ€™s professional standing, the contingency of compensation, the beneficial results obtained, and the customary legal fees for similar services. Â Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991); Lanier v. Lanier, 364 S.C. 211, 222, 612 S.E.2d 456, 461-62 (Ct. App. 2005); see alsoÂ  Messer v. Messer, 359 S.C. 614, 633, 598 S.E.2d 310, 320 (Ct. App. 2004) (refusing to find an abuse of discretion as to award of attorneyâ€™s fees when the family court analyzed each of the factors, detailed its findings in its final order, and those findings were supported by affidavits). 
Applying the Glasscock factors, the family court noted this litigation involved multiple issues, lasted five days, and transpired over a three month period.Â  Wifeâ€™s attorney has been a member of the South Carolina Bar since 1978, his fees were consistent with legal fees for similar services, and Wife obtained a beneficial result. Moreover, Wifeâ€™s financial circumstances necessitated an award of attorneyâ€™s fees. The family court evaluated the reasonableness of Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees and costs, her attorneyâ€™s extensive experience and standing in the Bar, and the number of hours involved in this litigation against the backdrop of Husbandâ€™s failure to comply with the provisions of the divorce decree and his failure to accurately report income in his financial declaration. We, therefore, affirm the family courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the family courtâ€™s decision is 
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

title: State v. Claypoole
description: The Court of Appeals affirmed the trial court's denial of defendant Claypoole's motion for a directed verdict on the charge of accessory before the fact to criminal sexual conduct with a minor in the second degree.  Claypoole, mother of the minor victim, argued that while she allowed her husband to have sexual intercourse with her daughter from a previous marriage, she did not urge, aid, or advise her husband to commit the substantive offense.  The Court of Appeals disagreed, holding that Claypoole's knowledge of her husband's previous misconduct as well as her actions and words of approval conveyed to her husband and daughter made her an active party to the substantive offense, thus warranting the denial of Claypoole's motion for a directed verdict.
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Theresa Claypoole, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4189
Heard October 10, 2006 â€“ Filed December 21, 2006Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves,Â  all of Columbia; Â and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  A Lexington County jury convicted Theresa Claypoole (Claypoole) of contributing to the delinquency of a minor andÂ  accessory before the fact to criminal sexual conduct with a minor.Â  Claypoole appeals her conviction of accessory before the fact, claiming the trial court should have directed a verdict in her favor due to insufficient evidence.Â  We affirm.

FACTS 
Beginning in 1999, Kermit Claypoole (Kermit) resided with Claypoole and her two daughters from a previous marriage, K.H. and E.H. Â During this time, Kermit engaged in conversations with the two daughters that were sexual in nature.Â  E.H., Claypooleâ€™s older daughter, testified that Kermit would ask the girls if they wanted to have â€œfunâ€ with him, while rubbing E.H.â€™s arm in â€œa sexual sense.â€Â  Both K.H. and E.H. admitted they told their mother of Kermitâ€™s actions with Claypooleâ€™s reassurance that she would talk with Kermit about his behavior.
Shortly thereafter, the girls told their biological father about Kermitâ€™s advances.Â  Based on this information and Kermitâ€™s previous conviction of two counts of criminal sexual conduct with a minor, the court granted the biological father sole custody of the girls; however, by September of 2001, they again resided with their mother and Kermit in South Carolina.Â  
Over the next several months, Claypoole often left the girls alone with Kermit, despite her knowledge that Kermit was a registered sex offender and that a court order prohibited any contact between him and the girls.Â  During Claypooleâ€™s absence, Kermit re-initiated conversations with E.H. and K.H. about sex.Â  Once again, Claypoole reassured E.H. that she would talk to Kermit about his inappropriate interactions with the girls; however, E.H.â€™s journal entries indicate Claypoole took no action.Â  She wrote, â€œHey, last night I heard the worst thing, the sound of my little sis f[â€¦]ing.Â  [M]om is not afraid of [K.H.] getting knocked up.Â  Now that is whack[1].â€ Â While E.H. did not engage in any sexual acts with Kermit, her younger sister, K.H., admitted to having sex with Kermit, which resulted in her pregnancy.Â  
K.H. also acknowledged that Kermit told her mother about the sexual relationship, and her mother then told K.H. to have sex with Kermit as long as it felt good.Â  Regarding the propriety of Claypooleâ€™s forty-nine-year-old husband sleeping with her thirteen-year-old daughter, Claypoole stated she did not know why everyone made such a big deal out of them having sex because in West Virginia, where she was raised, the older men often taught young girls about sex to prepare them for their wedding nights. 
After the Stateâ€™s presentation of evidence, Claypoole moved for a directed verdict as to the accessory before the fact charge.Â  Claypoole renewed this motion after the close of evidence, and the court again denied this motion.Â  The jury found Claypoole guilty of accessory before the fact to criminal sexual conduct with a minor and contributing to the delinquency of a minor.Â  The trial court sentenced Claypoole to concurrent terms of ten years for accessory before the fact and three years for contributing to the delinquency of a minor, all terms suspended to five-years probation.Â  This appeal follows. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Claypoole argues the trial court erred in failing to direct a verdict for the charge of accessory before the fact as the evidence offered by the State was insufficient as a matter of law to sustain the juryâ€™s conviction.Â  We disagree.
â€œWhen ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not its weight.â€Â  State v. Weston, 367 S.C. 279, 292, 625 S.E.2d 641, 648 (2006).Â  Furthermore, a defendant is entitled to a directed verdict at the trial level when the State does not produce evidence of the offense charged; however, if the State presents any evidence at trial which reasonably tends to prove the defendantâ€™s guilt, the case must go to the jury.Â  State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 103, 610 S.E.2d 494, 500 (2005); State v. Ezell, 321 S.C. 421, 424, 468 S.E.2d 679, 680 (Ct. App. 1996) (emphasis added).Â  
In deciding whether the trial court erred in failing to direct a verdict in favor of a defendant in a criminal case, the appellate court must view the testimony in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Massey, 267 S.C. 432, 442, 229 S.E.2d 332, 337 (1976).Â  If there is any direct or substantial circumstantial evidence tending to prove the guilt of the accused, or from which guilt may be fairly and logically deduced, the case should be submitted to the jury.Â  Sellers v. State, 362 S.C. 182, 189, 607 S.E.2d 82, 85 (2005).
Claypoole argues the State failed to establish the requisite elements of accessory before the fact to criminal sexual conduct to justify her conviction.Â  Criminal sexual conduct with a minor in the second degree is defined as â€œsexual battery with a victim who is fourteen years of age or less but who is at least eleven years of age.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-655(2) (1984) (current version at S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-655(B) (2005)).[2]Â  The State must prove: (1) the accused advised and agreed, urged, or in some way aided some other person to commit the offense; (2) the accused was not present when the offense was committed; and (3) some principal committed the offense.Â  State v. Farne, 190 S.C. 75, 84, 1 S.E.2d 912, 915-16 (1939). 
Neither party presented evidence that Claypoole was present when the sexual misconduct occurred. Â The uncontroverted testimony establishes that the principal, Kermit, committed the substantive offense of criminal sexual misconduct.Â  Consequently, for Claypoole to be an accessory before the fact, she must have advised, agreed, urged or in some way aided Kermit to commit criminal sexual misconduct against K.H. 
While Claypoole admits she was negligent in â€œfoolishly fail[ing] to pick up on her childrenâ€™s hints at improper conduct,â€ she argues the State presented no evidence that she either knew about the conduct or actively aided Kermit in his actions.Â  We find this argument to be without merit.Â Â  
Our sister state of North Carolina has dealt with a similar issue in State v. Walden, 306 N.C. 466, 293 S.E.2d 780 (1982).Â  In that case, the North Carolina Supreme Court upheld the trial courtâ€™s conviction of a mother for aiding and abetting an assault with a deadly weapon by another person against her child when the mother permitted another person to severely beat her son in the motherâ€™s presence.Â  Id.
In general, North Carolina law on aiding and abetting requires a person to say or do something to demonstrate consent to a felonious purpose and to contribute to the execution of a crime. [3] Â  Id. at 476, 293 S.E.2d at 787.Â  The court in Walden recognized a person is under no general duty to prevent the commission of a crime solely because that person is present; however, the court also acknowledged the nature of the parent-child relationship places a legal duty upon the parent to take all reasonable steps to protect the child from harm.Â  Id. at 472, 293 S.E.2d at 784; Id. at 475, 293 S.E.2d at 786.Â  Thus, a parentâ€™s failure â€œto take all steps reasonably possible to protect the parentâ€™s child from an attack by another person constitutes an act of omission by the parent showing the parentâ€™s consent and contribution to the crime being committed.â€Â  Id. at 476, 293 S.E.2d at 787.Â  
Like the mother in Walden, Claypoole was aware that her child was at risk of suffering injury at the hands of another, and she was in a position to prevent the offense against her child. Â Unlike the mother in Walden, Claypoole was not present when the substantive offenses against K.H. were committed. Â However, this Court finds the North Carolina Supreme Courtâ€™s reasoning in Walden persuasive and instructive in deciding this matter. 
The State presented sufficient evidence that Claypoole aided and encouraged Kermit in committing criminal sexual conduct against K.H.Â  In 1999 and 2001, E.H. told her mother about Kermitâ€™s inappropriate comments and invitations to have â€œfun,â€ and Claypoole promised to talk with Kermit.Â  K.H. testified that her mother knew about Kermitâ€™s sexual innuendos as well as her sexual relationship with Kermit.Â  When Kermit told Claypoole about the sex, and Claypoole subsequently told K.H. it was all right as long as it felt good, [4] Claypoole was no longer a passive party.Â  Her approval, conveyed to both K.H. and Kermit, effectively aided and encouraged Kermit in his actions against K.H.Â  
Furthermore, Claypoole allowed Kermit to reside in the same house with the girls, thus aiding him in the commission of these acts.Â  She was fully aware a court order prohibited any contact between Kermit and the girls, but she did nothing to prevent the situation.Â  In addition, when Claypoole learned Kermit was having sex with K.H., she continued to aid Kermit by her failure to stop him from having sex with K.H.Â  E.H.â€™s journal entries reveal that Claypoole agreed to this conduct by ignoring E.H.â€™s complaints and appearing to be unconcerned with the prospect of K.H. becoming pregnant.Â  Finally, Claypoole showed her approval and apparent lack of concern for Kermitâ€™s actions by telling her neighbor that she did not understand why everyone was so concerned with Kermit and K.H. having sex.Â  According to the neighborâ€™s testimony, Claypoole stated that permitting older men to have sex with young girls was a good way to teach them about sex.Â  
Claypooleâ€™s consistent failure to prevent this misconduct or otherwise protect K.H. and her decision to live with Kermit, despite the presence of her children, constituted consent and encouragement to the commission of this crime.Â  Given the foregoing, sufficient evidence exists to sustain Claypooleâ€™s conviction of accessory before the fact to criminal sexual conduct with a minor. 
CONCLUSION
This Court is not concerned with the weight of evidence, only its existence. Â The State presented direct and substantial circumstantial evidence that Claypoole was an accessory before the fact to criminal sexual conduct; thus, we hold the trial court properly denied Claypooleâ€™s motion for a directed verdict.
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.Â  
GOOLSBY and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] E.H.â€™s journal entry, which she read during her testimony, reflects her disdain over her motherâ€™s indifference towards Kermitâ€™s illicit relationship with K.H.Â  The court reporter, unfamiliar with the slang term â€œwack,â€ misquoted E.H.Â  The absence of â€œhâ€ in â€œwackâ€ differentiates it from â€œwhack,â€ which means â€œto strike with a smart or resounding blow.â€Â  See Merriam Websterâ€™s Collegiate Dictionary 1344 (10th ed. 1993).Â  â€œWack,â€ as defined in the Urban Dictionary and used in this context, means â€œappalling.â€ Â See The Urban Dictionary 331 (2005). 
[2] Because Claypooleâ€™s misconduct occurred in 2001, the court cites to the 2001 version of S.C. Code Ann. Â§16-3-655 as amended. Â While the legislature has revised this section since 2001, it did not alter the substantive statutory language for criminal sexual conduct with a minor in the second degree as applied to Claypoole.
[3] In distinguishing the crime of accessory before the fact from aiding and abetting, the North Carolina Supreme Court stated: â€œThe distinction between the two . . . lies in the elements of presence or absence at the time the crime is being committed.Â  An accessory before the fact must be absent from the scene of the offense, while an aider and abettor must be actually or constructively present at the scene.â€Â  State v. Graham, 303 N.C. 521, 525, 279 S.E.2d 588, 591 (1981).Â  Similarly, to aid and abet in South Carolina, one must â€œ[help], assist, or facilitate the commission of [the] crime, promote the accomplishment thereof, help in advancing or bringing it about, or encourage, counsel, or incite [the] commission [of the crime].â€Â  State v. Smith, 359 S.C. 481, 491, 597 S.E.2d 888, 892 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 68 (6th ed. 1990)).Â  While the law distinguishes these two crimes based on oneâ€™s presence or lack thereof, the required substantive actions are virtually the same to render one guilty as an accessory or an aider and abettor.
[4] Claypoole argues for the first time during oral argument that the circuit court improperly considered this statement.Â  She argues the court should not have used the stateâ€™s reply testimony in considering Claypooleâ€™s directed verdict motion.Â  We reiterate that the court, in ruling on a directed verdict motion, can consider any evidence presented by the State, which tends to prove a defendantâ€™s guilt. See Ezell, 321 S.C. at 424, 468 S.E.2d at
680.

title: Ross v. Ligand Pharmaceuticals, Inc.
description: Ligand Pharmaceuticals, Inc. appeals the circuit court's order awarding wages, treble damages, and attoney's fees to Richard Ross for Ligand's breach of an employment contract, violation of the South Carolina Payment of Wages Act, and violation of public policy.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Richard Ross, Respondent,
v.
Ligand Pharmaceuticals, Inc., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4190
Heard October 12, 2006 â€“ Filed December 21, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Joseph D. Thompson, III, Lydia B. Applegate, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Donald Higgins Howe, Robert J. Wyndham, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â Â Â Â  Ligand Pharmaceuticals, Inc. appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order awarding wages, treble damages, and attorneyâ€™s fees to Richard Ross for Ligandâ€™s breach of an employment contract, violation of the South Carolina Payment of Wages Act, and violation of public policy.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
In October 1998, Ligand offered Ross a position as a Senior Oncology Specialist (SOS).Â  The offer provided a starting salary of $7,166.67 per month and participation â€œin the 1998 Sales Force Incentive Plan based upon achievement of pre-agreed impact goals and/or sales objectives.â€Â  The offer further provided that â€œ[a]ny additions or modifications to these terms would have to be in writing and signed by [Ross] and the Company President.â€Â  Ross accepted the offer and began work with Ligand on November 3, 1998.
Initially, Ross did not participate in a sales incentive plan because Ligand did not have an approved product for distribution; instead, Ross participated in a Management by Objective Plan that presumably provided for incentives based on non-sales related criteria.Â  Sometime in 1999, Ligandâ€™s first product was approved.Â  Subsequently, Ross began participating in the 1999 Sales Force Incentive Compensation Plan (1999 Plan) that permitted him to earn up to thirty-five percent of his salary.Â  The 1999 Plan based compensation on a mathematical formula applied to sales each quarter.Â  Â Â 
Throughout his employment with Ligand, Ross participated in yearly compensation plans similar to the 1999 Plan.Â  In 2001, however, Ligand changed the plan to provide compensation based on trimester sales.Â  In addition, Ligand altered the compensation plan to provide:Â  â€œIn order to be eligible for the trimester incentive compensation payout, [an employee] must be employed at the time the trimester sales incentive compensation payouts are distributed.â€Â  These changes were included in the incentive plans for 2001, 2002, and 2003. Â Â 
In April of 2002, Ligand promoted Ross to Regional Business Manager (RBM).Â  The promotion allowed Ross to participate in the Oncology Regional Business Managers Plan (RBM Plan).Â  The RBM Plan provides:Â  â€œThe Incentive Plan payout will be paid following the conclusion of each trimester period according to the following estimated schedule:Â  Â Â 

  
    
      Trimester 1
        Payout  
       June 30, 2003
    
    
       
      
    
    
      Trimester 2
        Payout       
       October 31, 2003
    
    
       
      
    
    
      Trimester 3
        Payout  
       February 28, 2004.â€
    
  

The â€œtarget datesâ€ for the RBM Plan mirrored the scheduled payout dates for the 2001 and 2002 incentive plans.Â  
Ross resigned from Ligand on October 15, 2003.Â  Rossâ€™s resignation was effective forty-five days after August 31, 2003, the date the second trimester of 2003 ended.Â  Ligand distributed the payouts for the second trimester of 2003 sometime after November 15, 2003.Â  Ligand declined to pay Ross the incentive plan payout of $12,000 for the second trimester of 2003 because the RBM Plan required that a person must be employed by Ligand, in good standing, at the time the incentive compensation checks were distributed.
Thereafter, Ross filed an action against Ligand alleging the refusal to pay the incentive payout breached the employment agreement and violated the South Carolina Payment of Wages Act.Â  The circuit court held the RBM Plan violated sections 41-10-30, 41-10-40, 41-10-50, and 41-10-100 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) and public policy. Â The court also held Ligand breached the employment agreement.Â  The circuit court awarded Ross $36,000 as treble damages pursuant to section 41-10-80 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005), attorneyâ€™s fees totaling $18,000, and costs in the amount of $837.60.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  The trial judgeâ€™s findings are equivalent to a juryâ€™s findings in a law action.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Payment of Wages Act
Ligand argues the trial judge erred in finding Ligand violated sections 41-10-30 and 41-10-40 of the South Carolina Payment of Wages Act.Â  We disagree.Â  
Section 41-10-30 provides, in relevant part: 

(A) Every employer shall notify each employee in writing at the time of hiring of the normal hours and wages agreed upon, the time and place of payment, and the deductions which will be made from the wages, including payments to insurance programs. The employer has the option of giving written notification by posting the terms conspicuously at or near the place of work. Any changes in these terms must be made in writing at least seven calendar days before they become effective. This section does not apply to wage increases.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 41-10-30 (Supp. 2005) (emphasis added).Â  
At trial, Ligand argued the establishment of the â€œtarget datesâ€ in the RBM Plan sufficiently complied with the time and place of payment requirements of section 40-10-30.Â  The trial judge found Ligand violated section 41-10-30â€™s requirement to provide the date and place of payment because the estimated schedule and â€œtarget datesâ€ in the RBM Plan did not provide a time for payment as required by the Payment of Wages Act.Â Â  We find sufficient evidence supports this finding.Â  The RBM Plan provides incentive payouts will be paid according to an estimated schedule with payment on the â€œtarget date.â€Â  In addition, payouts are contingent upon an employee such as Ross being â€œemployed at the time the [payouts] are distributed.â€Â  Ligand admitted the employee must be employed on the date it ultimately issued the checks, not on the â€œtarget date.â€Â  Ligand testified:

Q:Â  And as I understand your position, the policy of Ligand is in order to get your incentive compensation payment for a particular trimester, you had to be employed when Ligand wrote the check?
A (Ligand):Â  That is correct.
Q:Â  Which could have been on the target date, could have been later? 
A:Â  That is correct.
Q:Â  It could have been whenever Ligand decided to write that check, correct?
A:Â  Correct.
Q:Â  And your position is that if you all decided not to write this check for a year and Mr. Ross was not present, then he would not be entitled to the $12,000?
A:Â  That is correct.

Ligand added the estimated payment schedule serves â€œno purpose, whatsoever, other than guidance to the field.â€Â  Moreover, the record demonstrates Ligand frequently distributed incentive payout checks after the date listed in the estimated scheduleâ€”with four of the previous ten payments being distributed after the â€œtarget date.â€ 
We agree with the trial judgeâ€™s determination that Ligand fails to satisfy the statutory requirements of section 40-10-30 because Ligand provided employees with no time certain for when payment would occur.Â  Ligand admitted the key to receiving the earned bonus was the date it arbitrarily selected for distribution of the checks not the â€œtarget datesâ€ from the estimated schedule provided to Ross.Â  Providing estimated payment dates that serve â€œno purpose whatsoeverâ€ and are dependent upon employees being employed at the time payouts are distributed, whenever that may be, clearly does not provide notice of â€œtime and date of payment.â€Â  Accordingly, we affirm the trial judgeâ€™s finding that the RBM Plan violates section 41-10-30.
Ligand also relies on Rice v. Multimedia, Inc., 318 S.C. 95, 456 S.E.2d 381 (1995), in support of its argument that the RBM Plan complied with the time and place mandates of section 40-10-30.Â  In Rice, an employee sought payment for commissions due on advertising contracts under the Payment of Wages Act.Â  Id. at 95, 456 S.E.2d at 381.Â  The parties had a contract providing that sales commissions would be paid to a departing employee only for those advertisements sold by the employee and actually broadcast in the month in which the employee left the company.Â  Id. at 96, 456 S.E.2d at 382.Â  When the employer refused to pay certain commissions after Rice left the company, Rice sued arguing the departure policy was void as against public policy.Â  Id. at 100, 456 S.E.2d at 384.Â  The supreme court disagreed and found the agreement enforceable.Â  Id.Â  The court found the agreement was â€œnot arbitrary nor does it violate any law,â€ because the agreement was customary to the industry and provided a valid economic purposeâ€”â€œto ensure that the salesperson gives continuing service to the client after the sale[.]Â  Id.Â  
We find the factual scenario in this matter distinguishable from Rice for three reasons.Â  First, unlike the agreement in Rice which was challenged on the ground of public policy rather than because of any violation of the Payment of Wages Act, we have found Ligandâ€™s policy violated both sections 40-10-30 and 40-10-40 of the Act.Â  Second, the RBM Plan serves no legitimate purpose, whereas the policy in Rice had a clear, legitimate economic purpose; even Ligand admitted its policy serves â€œno purpose whatsoever.â€Â  And third, the Rice agreement was not arbitrary as it established, in clear terms, the time certain for payment of the commission.Â  In our case, the time for payment was entirely dependant upon Ligandâ€™s arbitrary decision of when to issue the commission check to Ross, whenever that date may be, and was not based on any economic reason.Â  In other words, the policy in Rice merely established the manner the company would pay admittedly owed commissions, whereas Ligand, under its policy, would not even admit the commissions were due to Ross unless he was employed by Ligand when it ultimately decided to pay them.Â  Therefore, Ligandâ€™s reliance on Rice is misplaced.
Ligand next contends the circuit court erred in finding Ligand violated section 41-10-40.Â  We disagree. 
Section 41-10-40(D) provides â€œ[e]very employer in the State shall pay all wages due at the time and place designated as required by subsection (A) of Â§ 41-10-30.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-10-40(D) (Supp. 2005). Â The trial judge held Ligand violated this section because the company failed to provide Ross with the time that wages earned and due under the RBM Plan would be paid.Â  Evidence exists to support this finding.Â  
Ligand admitted the commissions Ross sought were from sales made during the final trimester in which he worked for the company, and that he was in good standing with Ligand when the trimester ended and when he resigned.Â  Additionally, at the conclusion of Rossâ€™ final trimester, there was noting more that he was required to do or participate in to determine the amount of compensation due under the RBM Plan.Â  The sole reason Ligand failed to pay the wages earned during Rossâ€™ final trimester was that Ross was not employed when it finally issued the compensation checks, which was several weeks after its own target date had passed.Â  Moreover, as discussed above, Ligandâ€™s policy failed to provide the time and place for payment of commissions earned under the RBM Plan; therefore, the failure to provide the time and place of payment prevented Ligand from being able to pay wages due to Ross at the time and place designated as mandated by section 40-10-40(D).Â  Accordingly, we affirm the trial judgeâ€™s finding that Ligand violated section 41-10-40.
II.Â  Treble Damages and Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Ligand also contends the trial judge erred in awarding treble damages and attorneyâ€™s fees to Ross.Â  We disagree. 
When reviewing the award of treble damages, this court can take its own view of the facts. Â Oâ€™Neal v. Intermedical Hosp. of S.C., 355 S.C. 499, 509-10, 585 S.E.2d 526, 532 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing The Father v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 353 S.C. 254, 578 S.E.2d 11 (2003)). Generally, treble damages may be awarded when the withholding of wages was unreasonable and there was no good faith dispute.Â  Id.; see also Rice v. Multimedia, Inc., 318 S.C. 95, 98, 456 S.E.2d 381, 383 (1995).Â  
As our courts have stated: â€œIf there is a dispute over unpaid wages the employer
acts at his peril and the court in its discretion may award treble damages when the withholding was unreasonable and there was no good faith wage dispute,â€ and that â€œthe legislature intended to punish the employer who forces the employee to resort to the court in an unreasonable or bad faith wage dispute.â€Â  Rice, 318 S.C. at 99, 456 S.E.2d at 383.Â  Section 41-10-80 provides for the trebling of damages for violation of the Payment of Wage Act:Â  

In case of any failure to pay wages due to an employee as required by
Section 41-10-40 or 41-10-50 the employee may recover in a civil action an amount equal to three times the full amount of the unpaid wages, plus costs and reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees as the court may allow. Any civil action for the recovery of wages must be commenced within three years after the wages become due.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-10-80(C) (Supp. 2005).Â  
Ligand admitted the key to receiving the earned bonus was the date Ligand arbitrarily selected for distribution of the checks not the â€œtarget datesâ€ from the estimated schedule provided to Ross.Â  We agree with the trial judge that providing estimated payment dates that serve â€œno purpose whatsoeverâ€ and are dependent upon employees being employed at the time payouts are distributed, whenever that may be, is arbitrary and unreasonable.Â  Ligand admitted the commissions Ross sought were from sales made during the final trimester in which he worked for the company, and that he was in good standing with Ligand when the trimester ended and when he resigned.Â  Additionally, at the conclusion of Rossâ€™s final trimester, there was nothing more that he was required to do or participate in to determine the amount of compensation due under the RBM Plan.Â  The sole reason Ligand failed to pay the wages earned during Rossâ€™s final trimester was that Ross was not employed when it finally issued the compensation checks several weeks after the target date had passed.Â  Moreover, as discussed above, Ligandâ€™s policy failed to provide the time and place for payment of commissions earned under the RBM Plan, and this failure prevented Ligand from being able to pay wages due to Ross under the Payment of Wages Act.Â  Accordingly, we agree with the trial judge that Ligandâ€™s policy was based on its unilateral, arbitrary decision on when to issue compensation and that no good faith dispute existed.Â  Therefore, Ross is entitled to treble damages and attorneyâ€™s fees under section 41-10-80(C).Â Â Â  Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is hereby
 AFFIRMED.[1]
STILWELL and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â  

[1] In light of our disposition of this case, we need not address Appellantâ€™s remaining issues relating to (1) the circuit courtâ€™s finding that the compensation plan violates public policy or (2) the breach of contract action. Â See 
Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (stating appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).Â  Â However, one issue that warrants discussion is whether Ross consented to the terms of the agreement and is estopped from challenging the policy after his departure.Â  The trial judge found this argument to be without merit because the agreement was void and unenforceable under the Payment of Wages Act.Â  We agree.Â  Section 40-10-100 provides that â€œno provision of this chapter may be contravened or set aside by a private agreement.â€Â  Additionally, in Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., the supreme court reiterated South Carolinaâ€™s policy underlying the Payment of Wages Act, stating that our courts â€œrefuse to allow employers to ignore the statute by claiming their employees had by contract or custom waived their statutory right to prompt payment of wages.â€Â  335 S.C. 598, 605, 518 S.E.2d 591, 594 (1999).Â  The RBM Plan sought to set aside the requirement of the Act that Employers must provide a â€œtime and place of paymentâ€ to employees.Â  As we have held, the arbitrary date of the issuance of the commission checks at the discretion of Ligand is insufficient to comply with the Act.Â  Therefore, any agreement Ross may have consented to would be void under section 40-10-100, and unenforceable against him by Ligand.
